### Create Command Dialog with Keyboard Shortcut

Source: https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/components/command

Implements a CommandDialog component that opens/closes with a keyboard shortcut (Cmd/Ctrl + J). Displays command groups with icons from lucide-react and keyboard shortcuts. The dialog listens for keyboard events and prevents default browser behavior when the shortcut is triggered.

```tsx
"use client"

import * as React from "react"
import {
  Calculator,
  Calendar,
  CreditCard,
  Settings,
  Smile,
  User,
} from "lucide-react"

import {
  CommandDialog,
  CommandEmpty,
  CommandGroup,
  CommandInput,
  CommandItem,
  CommandList,
  CommandSeparator,
  CommandShortcut,
} from "@/components/ui/command"

export function CommandDialogDemo() {
  const [open, setOpen] = React.useState(false)

  React.useEffect(() => {
    const down = (e: KeyboardEvent) => {
      if (e.key === "j" && (e.metaKey || e.ctrlKey)) {
        e.preventDefault()
        setOpen((open) => !open)
      }
    }

    document.addEventListener("keydown", down)
    return () => document.removeEventListener("keydown", down)
  }, [])

  return (
    <>
      <p className="text-muted-foreground text-sm">
        Press{" "}
        <kbd className="bg-muted text-muted-foreground pointer-events-none inline-flex h-5 items-center gap-1 rounded border px-1.5 font-mono text-[10px] font-medium opacity-100 select-none">
          <span className="text-xs">âŒ˜</span>J
        </kbd>
      </p>
      <CommandDialog open={open} onOpenChange={setOpen}>
        <CommandInput placeholder="Type a command or search..." />
        <CommandList>
          <CommandEmpty>No results found.</CommandEmpty>
          <CommandGroup heading="Suggestions">
            <CommandItem>
              <Calendar />
              <span>Calendar</span>
            </CommandItem>
            <CommandItem>
              <Smile />
              <span>Search Emoji</span>
            </CommandItem>
            <CommandItem>
              <Calculator />
              <span>Calculator</span>
            </CommandItem>
          </CommandGroup>
          <CommandSeparator />
          <CommandGroup heading="Settings">
            <CommandItem>
              <User />
              <span>Profile</span>
              <CommandShortcut>âŒ˜P</CommandShortcut>
            </CommandItem>
            <CommandItem>
              <CreditCard />
              <span>Billing</span>
              <CommandShortcut>âŒ˜B</CommandShortcut>
            </CommandItem>
            <CommandItem>
              <Settings />
              <span>Settings</span>
              <CommandShortcut>âŒ˜S</CommandShortcut>
            </CommandItem>
          </CommandGroup>
        </CommandList>
      </CommandDialog>
    </>
  )
}
```

### Interactive Drawer with State Management and Chart in React

Source: https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/components/drawer

Demonstrates an advanced Drawer component with React state management, interactive buttons for adjusting values, and a Recharts BarChart visualization. The component manages a goal value between 200-400 and displays real-time updates with increase/decrease buttons and visual feedback via a bar chart.

```tsx
"use client"

import * as React from "react"
import { Minus, Plus } from "lucide-react"
import { Bar, BarChart, ResponsiveContainer } from "recharts"

import { Button } from "@/components/ui/button"
import {
  Drawer,
  DrawerClose,
  DrawerContent,
  DrawerDescription,
  DrawerFooter,
  DrawerHeader,
  DrawerTitle,
  DrawerTrigger,
} from "@/components/ui/drawer"

const data = [
  { goal: 400 },
  { goal: 300 },
  { goal: 200 },
  { goal: 300 },
  { goal: 200 },
  { goal: 278 },
  { goal: 189 },
  { goal: 239 },
  { goal: 300 },
  { goal: 200 },
  { goal: 278 },
  { goal: 189 },
  { goal: 349 },
]

export function DrawerDemo() {
  const [goal, setGoal] = React.useState(350)

  function onClick(adjustment: number) {
    setGoal(Math.max(200, Math.min(400, goal + adjustment)))
  }

  return (
    <Drawer>
      <DrawerTrigger asChild>
        <Button variant="outline">Open Drawer</Button>
      </DrawerTrigger>
      <DrawerContent>
        <div className="mx-auto w-full max-w-sm">
          <DrawerHeader>
            <DrawerTitle>Move Goal</DrawerTitle>
            <DrawerDescription>Set your daily activity goal.</DrawerDescription>
          </DrawerHeader>
          <div className="p-4 pb-0">
            <div className="flex items-center justify-center space-x-2">
              <Button
                variant="outline"
                size="icon"
                className="h-8 w-8 shrink-0 rounded-full"
                onClick={() => onClick(-10)}
                disabled={goal <= 200}
              >
                <Minus />
                <span className="sr-only">Decrease</span>
              </Button>
              <div className="flex-1 text-center">
                <div className="text-7xl font-bold tracking-tighter">
                  {goal}
                </div>
                <div className="text-muted-foreground text-[0.70rem] uppercase">
                  Calories/day
                </div>
              </div>
              <Button
                variant="outline"
                size="icon"
                className="h-8 w-8 shrink-0 rounded-full"
                onClick={() => onClick(10)}
                disabled={goal >= 400}
              >
                <Plus />
                <span className="sr-only">Increase</span>
              </Button>
            </div>
            <div className="mt-3 h-[120px]">
              <ResponsiveContainer width="100%" height="100%">
                <BarChart data={data}>
                  <Bar
                    dataKey="goal"
                    style={
                      {
                        fill: "hsl(var(--foreground))",
                        opacity: 0.9,
                      } as React.CSSProperties
                    }
                  />
                </BarChart>
              </ResponsiveContainer>
            </div>
          </div>
          <DrawerFooter>
            <Button>Submit</Button>
            <DrawerClose asChild>
              <Button variant="outline">Cancel</Button>
            </DrawerClose>
          </DrawerFooter>
        </div>
      </DrawerContent>
    </Drawer>
  )
}
```

### Extend Third-Party Component Without Replacing

Source: https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/registry/namespace

Pattern for extending vendor components by keeping the original and adding custom extensions. Uses registryDependencies to import the base component and adds new functionality in a separate file.

```json
{
  "name": "extended-table",
  "registryDependencies": ["@vendor/table"],
  "files": [
    {
      "path": "components/ui/table-extended.tsx",
      "content": "import { Table } from '@vendor/table'\n// Add your extensions\nexport function ExtendedTable() { ... }"
    }
  ]
}
```

import { Button } from "@/components/ui/button"
import {
  Field,

export function FieldResponsive() {

### Define a full shadcn/ui registry item configuration

Source: https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/registry/registry-item-json

This JSON configuration defines a complete shadcn/ui registry item, including its unique name, type, human-readable title, and descriptive text. It specifies both npm package dependencies and references to other registry items, along with the file paths for its components and custom CSS variables for thematic styling.

```json
{
  "$schema": "https://ui.shadcn.com/schema/registry-item.json",
  "name": "hello-world",
  "type": "registry:block",
  "title": "Hello World",
  "description": "A simple hello world component.",
  "registryDependencies": [
    "button",
    "@acme/input-form",
    "https://example.com/r/foo"
  ],
  "dependencies": ["is-even@3.0.0", "motion"],
  "files": [
    {
      "path": "registry/new-york/hello-world/hello-world.tsx",
      "type": "registry:component"
    },
    {
      "path": "registry/new-york/hello-world/use-hello-world.ts",
      "type": "registry:hook"
    }
  ],
  "cssVars": {
    "theme": {
      "font-heading": "Poppins, sans-serif"
    },
    "light": {
      "brand": "20 14.3% 4.1%"
    },
    "dark": {
      "brand": "20 14.3% 4.1%"
    }
  }
}
```

### Configure Shadcn Registry with Multiple Authentication Methods (JSON)

Source: https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/registry/namespace

This advanced configuration demonstrates combining multiple authentication methods for a shadcn registry. It includes various headers like `Authorization` (Bearer token), `X-API-Key`, and `X-Workspace-Id`, along with a `version` parameter, all securely managed via environment variables for access to an enterprise registry.

```json
{
  "@enterprise": {
    "url": "https://api.enterprise.com/v2/registry/{name}",
    "headers": {
      "Authorization": "Bearer ${ACCESS_TOKEN}",
      "X-API-Key": "${API_KEY}",
      "X-Workspace-Id": "${WORKSPACE_ID}"
    },
    "params": {
      "version": "latest"
    }
  }
}
```

### Configure shadcn/ui import aliases in components.json

Source: https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/changelog

This JSON configuration updates the `components.json` file to define import aliases for shadcn/ui components, utilities, UI elements, libraries, and hooks. It's essential for projects using the new CLI to correctly resolve module paths, allowing customization of the alias prefix if needed.

```json
{
  "$schema": "https://ui.shadcn.com/schema.json",
  "style": "new-york",
  "tailwind": {
    // ...
  },
  "aliases": {
    "components": "@/components",
    "utils": "@/lib/utils",
    "ui": "@/components/ui",
    "lib": "@/lib",
    "hooks": "@/hooks"
  }
}

### Search Registry with search Command

Source: https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/cli

The search command queries component registries with optional filtering. Supports searching single or multiple registries with query strings, pagination controls, and registry aliases.

```bash
npx shadcn@latest search [registry]
```

```bash
npx shadcn@latest search @shadcn -q "button"
```

```bash
npx shadcn@latest search @shadcn @v0 @acme
```

```bash
npx shadcn@latest list @acme
```

```bash
Usage: shadcn search|list [options] <registries...>

search items from registries

Arguments:
  registries             the registry names or urls to search items from. Names
                         must be prefixed with @.

Options:
  -c, --cwd <cwd>        the working directory. defaults to the current directory.
  -q, --query <query>    query string
  -l, --limit <number>   maximum number of items to display per registry (default: "100")
  -o, --offset <number>  number of items to skip (default: "0")
  -h, --help             display help for command
```

Demonstrates a basic horizontal resizable panel layout with three panels (one main panel and two nested vertical panels). The ResizablePanelGroup wraps panels with ResizableHandle components between them to enable resizing. Each panel has a default size percentage that controls its initial width/height.

        </div>

      <ResizablePanel defaultSize={50}>

Source: https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/components/navigation-menu

Builds a responsive navigation menu component with multiple dropdown sections (Home, Components, Docs, List). Uses NavigationMenu primitives from Radix UI with conditional mobile viewport, maps over component arrays for dynamic content generation, and implements custom ListItem sub-components for consistent link styling.

"use client"

  {
    title: "Alert Dialog",

  },
  {
    title: "Hover Card",
    href: "/docs/primitives/hover-card",
    description:
      "For sighted users to preview content available behind a link.",
  },
  {

    description:

  },
  {
    title: "Scroll-area",
    href: "/docs/primitives/scroll-area",
    description: "Visually or semantically separates content.",
  },
  {
    title: "Tabs",
    href: "/docs/primitives/tabs",
    description:
      "A set of layered sections of contentâ€”known as tab panelsâ€”that are displayed one at a time.",
  },
  {
    title: "Tooltip",
    href: "/docs/primitives/tooltip",
    description:
      "A popup that displays information related to an element when the element receives keyboard focus or the mouse hovers over it.",
  },
]

export function NavigationMenuDemo() {
  const isMobile = useIsMobile()

  return (
    <NavigationMenu viewport={isMobile}>
      <NavigationMenuList className="flex-wrap">
        <NavigationMenuItem>
          <NavigationMenuTrigger>Home</NavigationMenuTrigger>
          <NavigationMenuContent>
            <ul className="grid gap-2 md:w-[400px] lg:w-[500px] lg:grid-cols-[.75fr_1fr]">
              <li className="row-span-3">
                <NavigationMenuLink asChild>
                  <a
                    className="from-muted/50 to-muted flex h-full w-full flex-col justify-end rounded-md bg-linear-to-b p-4 no-underline outline-hidden transition-all duration-200 select-none focus:shadow-md md:p-6"
                    href="/"
                  >
                    <div className="mb-2 text-lg font-medium sm:mt-4">

              <ListItem href="/docs/primitives/typography" title="Typography">
                Styles for headings, paragraphs, lists...etc
              </ListItem>
            </ul>
          </NavigationMenuContent>
        </NavigationMenuItem>
        <NavigationMenuItem>
          <NavigationMenuTrigger>Components</NavigationMenuTrigger>
          <NavigationMenuContent>
            <ul className="grid gap-2 sm:w-[400px] md:w-[500px] md:grid-cols-2 lg:w-[600px]">
              {components.map((component) => (
                <ListItem
                  key={component.title}
                  title={component.title}
                  href={component.href}
                >
                  {component.description}
                </ListItem>
              ))}
            </ul>
          </NavigationMenuContent>
        </NavigationMenuItem>
        <NavigationMenuItem>
          <NavigationMenuLink asChild className={navigationMenuTriggerStyle()}>
            <Link href="/docs">Docs</Link>
          </NavigationMenuLink>
        </NavigationMenuItem>
        <NavigationMenuItem className="hidden md:block">
          <NavigationMenuTrigger>List</NavigationMenuTrigger>
          <NavigationMenuContent>

                </NavigationMenuLink>

          </NavigationMenuContent>
        </NavigationMenuItem>
      </NavigationMenuList>

  )
}

### Implement React UI Component for Dark Mode Toggle

Source: https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/dark-mode/vite

This React component provides a UI for users to toggle between light, dark, and system themes. It utilizes the `useTheme` hook to access the `setTheme` function from the `ThemeProvider` context. The component integrates icons from `lucide-react` and UI primitives (Button, DropdownMenu) from Shadcn UI to create an accessible and visually appealing theme switcher.

```tsx
import { Moon, Sun } from "lucide-react"

import { Button } from "@/components/ui/button"
import {
  DropdownMenu,
  DropdownMenuContent,
  DropdownMenuItem,
  DropdownMenuTrigger,
} from "@/components/ui/dropdown-menu"
import { useTheme } from "@/components/theme-provider"

export function ModeToggle() {
  const { setTheme } = useTheme()

  return (
    <DropdownMenu>
      <DropdownMenuTrigger asChild>
        <Button variant="outline" size="icon">
          <Sun className="h-[1.2rem] w-[1.2rem] scale-100 rotate-0 transition-all dark:scale-0 dark:-rotate-90" />
          <Moon className="absolute h-[1.2rem] w-[1.2rem] scale-0 rotate-90 transition-all dark:scale-100 dark:-rotate-0" />
          <span className="sr-only">Toggle theme</span>
        </Button>
      </DropdownMenuTrigger>
      <DropdownMenuContent align="end">
        <DropdownMenuItem onClick={() => setTheme("light")}>
          Light
        </DropdownMenuItem>
        <DropdownMenuItem onClick={() => setTheme("dark")}>
          Dark
        </DropdownMenuItem>
        <DropdownMenuItem onClick={() => setTheme("system")}>
          System
        </DropdownMenuItem>
      </DropdownMenuContent>
    </DropdownMenu>
  )
}
```

### Create Next.js Theme Provider Component

Defines a reusable React component (`ThemeProvider`) that wraps `next-themes`'s `ThemeProvider`. This component enables theme context throughout the application, making theme state accessible to all child components.

```tsx
"use client"

import * as React from "react"
import { ThemeProvider as NextThemesProvider } from "next-themes"

export function ThemeProvider({
  children,
  ...props
}: React.ComponentProps<typeof NextThemesProvider>) {

}

// Example: Serverless function to handle Vercel webhook events
// This is a conceptual representation and requires actual implementation.

module.exports = (req, res) => {
  if (req.method === 'POST') {
    const payload = req.body;
    // Process the Vercel event payload (e.g., deployment status)

      console.log('Deployment finished:', payload.data.url);

};

### Get Installation

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/integrations/create-integration/marketplace-api

Retrieves installation details, including the notification field, using the GET /v1/installations/{installationId} endpoint.

```APIDOC
## GET /v1/installations/{installationId}

### Description
Retrieves the details of a specific installation, including any active notification.

### Method
GET

### Endpoint
`/v1/installations/{installationId}`

### Parameters
#### Path Parameters
- **installationId** (string) - Required - The unique identifier of the installation.

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
- **id** (string) - The installation ID.
- **notification** (object | null) - The notification object if one is set, otherwise null.
  - **title** (string) - The title of the notification.
  - **message** (string) - The main content of the notification.
  - **href** (string) - The URL linked in the notification.
  - **type** (string) - The severity type of the notification.

### Response Example
```json
{
  "id": "icfg_abc123",
  "notification": {
    "title": "Review your usage",
    "message": "Your monthly usage report is ready",
    "href": "sso:https://your-integration.com/dashboard/usage",
    "type": "info"
  }
}
```
```

### Get Installation with Notification Details (TypeScript)

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/integrations/create-integration/marketplace-api

Retrieves installation details, including any active notification, by calling the GET /v1/installations/{installationId} endpoint. The function checks if a notification exists and logs its title and message to the console. It returns the full installation object.

```typescript
async function getInstallation(installationId: string) {
  const response = await fetch(
    `https://api.vercel.com/v1/installations/${installationId}`,
    {
      headers: {
        'Authorization': `Bearer ${token}`,
      },
    }
  );

  const installation = await response.json();

  if (installation.notification) {
    console.log(`Notification: ${installation.notification.title}`);
    console.log(`Message: ${installation.notification.message}`);
  }

  return installation;
}
```

### Install and Verify Claude Code CLI and Anthropic SDK in Vercel Sandbox (TypeScript)

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/using-vercel-sandbox-claude-agent-sdk

This script automates the setup of a Vercel Sandbox environment. It installs the Claude Code CLI globally and the Anthropic SDK locally, then runs a verification script to confirm the SDK's functionality. The script requires the '@vercel/sandbox' package and the 'ms' utility for timeout configuration. It outputs installation progress and verification status, handling potential errors.

```typescript
import ms from 'ms';
import { Sandbox } from '@vercel/sandbox';

async function main() {
  const sandbox = await Sandbox.create({
    resources: {
      vcpus: 4,
    },
    // Timeout in milliseconds: ms('10m') = 600000
    // Defaults to 5 minutes. The maximum is 5 hours for Pro/Enterprise, and 45 minutes for Hobby.
    timeout: ms('10m'),
    runtime: 'node22',
  });

  console.log(`Sandbox created: ${sandbox.sandboxId}`);
  console.log(`Installing Claude Code CLI...`);

  // Install Claude Code CLI globally
  const installCLI = await sandbox.runCommand({
    cmd: 'npm',
    args: ['install', '-g', '@anthropic-ai/claude-code'],
    stderr: process.stderr,
    stdout: process.stdout,
    sudo: true,
  });

  if (installCLI.exitCode != 0) {
    console.log('installing Claude Code CLI failed');
    process.exit(1);
  }
  console.log(`âœ“ Claude Code CLI installed`);
  console.log(`Installing Anthropic SDK...`);

  // Install @anthropic-ai/sdk in the working directory
  const installSDK = await sandbox.runCommand({
    cmd: 'npm',
    args: ['install', '@anthropic-ai/sdk'],
    stderr: process.stderr,
    stdout: process.stdout,
  });

  if (installSDK.exitCode != 0) {
    console.log('installing Anthropic SDK failed');
    process.exit(1);
  }
  console.log(`âœ“ Anthropic SDK installed`);
  console.log(`Verifying SDK connection...`);

  // Create a simple script to verify the SDK can be imported
  const verifyScript = `
import Anthropic from '@anthropic-ai/sdk';
console.log('SDK imported successfully');
console.log('Anthropic SDK version:', Anthropic.VERSION);
console.log('SDK is ready to use');
`;

  await sandbox.writeFiles([
    {
      path: '/vercel/sandbox/verify.mjs',
      content: Buffer.from(verifyScript),
    },
  ]);

  // Run the verification script
  const verifyRun = await sandbox.runCommand({
    cmd: 'node',
    args: ['verify.mjs'],
    stderr: process.stderr,
    stdout: process.stdout,
  });

  if (verifyRun.exitCode != 0) {
    console.log('SDK verification failed');
    process.exit(1);
  }
  console.log(`âœ“ Anthropic SDK is properly connected`);
  console.log(`\nSuccess! Both Claude Code CLI and Anthropic SDK are installed and ready to use.`);

  // Stop the sandbox
  await sandbox.stop();
  console.log(`Sandbox stopped`);
}

main().catch(console.error);

```

### Create Session Store with Redis and Next.js (JavaScript)

Source: https://context7_llms

This guide demonstrates how to create a durable session store using Redis and Next.js on Vercel. It covers the setup and implementation for managing user sessions efficiently using Vercel KV, providing a persistent and fast session storage solution.

```javascript
import { Redis } from '@upstash/redis';

const redis = new Redis({
  url: process.env.REDIS_URL,
  token: process.env.REDIS_TOKEN,
});

export async function POST(request) {
  const { sessionId, userData } = await request.json();

  if (!sessionId || !userData) {
    return new Response(JSON.stringify({ message: 'Missing sessionId or userData' }), {
      status: 400,
      headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
    });
  }

  try {
    // Store session data in Redis with an expiration time (e.g., 1 hour)
    await redis.set(sessionId, JSON.stringify(userData), {
      ex: 3600, // Expires in 1 hour
    });

    return new Response(JSON.stringify({ message: 'Session stored successfully' }), {
      status: 200,
      headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
    });
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error storing session:', error);
    return new Response(JSON.stringify({ message: 'Failed to store session' }), {
      status: 500,
      headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
    });
  }
}

export async function GET(request) {
  const { searchParams } = new URL(request.url);
  const sessionId = searchParams.get('sessionId');

  if (!sessionId) {
    return new Response(JSON.stringify({ message: 'Missing sessionId' }), {
      status: 400,
      headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
    });
  }

  try {
    const userData = await redis.get(sessionId);
    if (userData === null) {
      return new Response(JSON.stringify({ message: 'Session not found' }), {
        status: 404,
        headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
      });
    }
    return new Response(userData, {
      headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
    });
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error retrieving session:', error);
    return new Response(JSON.stringify({ message: 'Failed to retrieve session' }), {
      status: 500,
      headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
    });
  }
}
```

### Implement Singleton Pattern for Stripe Instance in Next.js

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/getting-started-with-nextjs-typescript-stripe

Provides a TypeScript example of implementing the singleton pattern to efficiently load and reuse the Stripe instance in a Next.js application. This ensures Stripe.js is loaded only once, optimizing performance by preventing re-instantiation on every render. It exports a `getStripe` function that handles the creation and retrieval of the Stripe instance.

```typescript
import { Stripe, loadStripe } from '@stripe/stripe-js';

let stripePromise: Promise<Stripe | null>;

const getStripe = () => {
  if (!stripePromise) {
    stripePromise = loadStripe(process.env.NEXT_PUBLIC_STRIPE_PUBLISHABLE_KEY!);
  }
  return stripePromise;
};

export default getStripe;
```

### Deploy Puppeteer with Next.js on Vercel (Node.js)

Source: https://context7_llms

This guide covers setting up Puppeteer with Next.js on Vercel for headless browser automation. It includes a practical example for generating web page screenshots, detailing the necessary configurations and considerations for running Puppeteer in a serverless environment.

```javascript
import chromium from '@sparticuz/chromium';
import puppeteer from 'puppeteer';

export default async function handler(req, res) {
  const { url } = req.query;

  if (!url) {
    return res.status(400).send('URL parameter is required');
  }

  let browser = null;
  try {
    const executablePath = await chromium.executablePath;
    browser = await puppeteer.launch({
      args: chromium.args,
      executablePath: executablePath || process.env.CHROME_EXECUTABLE_PATH,
      headless: chromium.headless,
    });

    const page = await browser.newPage();
    await page.goto(url, {
      waitUntil: 'networkidle2',
    });

    const screenshot = await page.screenshot({
      type: 'png',
    });

    res.setHeader('Content-Type', 'image/png');
    res.status(200).send(screenshot);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error generating screenshot:', error);
    res.status(500).send('Error generating screenshot');
  } finally {
    if (browser) {
      await browser.close();
    }
  }
}
```

### Next.js API Route for On-Demand Revalidation

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/incremental-static-regeneration/quickstart

This example demonstrates an API route in Next.js (both Pages Router and App Router) that handles on-demand revalidation. It requires a secret token for authentication and uses `res.revalidate()` or `revalidatePath()` to refresh cached pages. Ensure the `MY_SECRET_TOKEN` environment variable is set.

```javascript
export default async function handler(request, response) {
  // Check for secret to confirm this is a valid request
  if (request.query.secret !== process.env.MY_SECRET_TOKEN) {
    return response.status(401).json({ message: 'Invalid token' });
  }

  try {
    // This should be the actual path, not a rewritten path
    // e.g. for "/blog-posts/[slug]" this should be "/blog-posts/1"
    await response.revalidate('/blog-posts');
    return response.json({ revalidated: true });
  } catch (err) {
    // If there was an error, Next.js will continue
    // to show the last successfully generated page
    return response.status(500).send('Error revalidating');
  }
}
```

```typescript
import type { NextApiRequest, NextApiResponse } from 'next';

export default async function handler(
  req: NextApiRequest,
  res: NextApiResponse,
) {
  // Check for secret to confirm this is a valid request
  if (req.query.secret !== process.env.MY_SECRET_TOKEN) {
    return res.status(401).json({ message: 'Invalid token' });
  }

  try {
    // This should be the actual path, not a rewritten path
    // e.g. for "/blog-posts/[slug]" this should be "/blog-posts/1"
    await res.revalidate('/blog-posts');
    return res.json({ revalidated: true });
  } catch (err) {
    // If there was an error, Next.js will continue
    // to show the last successfully generated page
    return res.status(500).send('Error revalidating');
  }
}
```

```typescript
import { revalidatePath } from 'next/cache';

export async function GET(request: Request) {
  const { searchParams } = new URL(request.url);
  if (searchParams.get('secret') !== process.env.MY_SECRET_TOKEN) {
    return new Response('Invalid credentials',
      {
        status: 401,
      }
    );
  }

  revalidatePath('/blog-posts');

  return Response.json({
    revalidated: true,
    now: Date.now(),
  });
}
```

```javascript

### Vercel SDK - Upload File and Create Deployment

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/ai-agents

Demonstrates how to use the Vercel SDK to upload project files and create a new deployment.

```APIDOC
## Vercel SDK - Upload File and Create Deployment

### Description
This example shows how to use the Vercel SDK to upload a zipped project as a file to Vercel and then create a deployment with that file. It includes calculating the file's SHA1 hash and setting necessary headers.

### Method
SDK methods: `vercel.deployments.uploadFile` and `vercel.deployments.createDeployment`

### Parameters
#### Path Parameters
None

#### Query Parameters
None

#### Request Body
**uploadFile**:
- **teamId** (string) - Required - The ID of the Vercel team.
- **headers** (object) - Required - Headers for the file upload, including Content-Type, x-vercel-digest (SHA1 hash), and Content-Length.
- **body** (Buffer) - Required - The zipped project files as a buffer.

**createDeployment**:
- **teamId** (string) - Required - The ID of the Vercel team.
- **requestBody** (object) - Required - The deployment details.
  - **files** (array) - Required - An array of file objects, each with 'file' (path) and 'sha' (hash).
  - **projectSettings** (object) - Optional - Project configuration, e.g., `framework`.
  - **name** (string) - Optional - A name for the deployment.

### Request Example
```typescript
import { Vercel } from "@vercel/sdk";
import crypto from "node:crypto";

const vercel = new Vercel({ bearerToken: "<YOUR_BEARER_TOKEN>" });
const teamId = process.env.TEAM_ID;

async function deployToVercel() {
  const fileBuffer = /* your zipped project files as a buffer */;
  const fileSha = crypto.createHash("sha1").update(fileBuffer).digest("hex");

  // 1. Upload the file to Vercel
  await vercel.deployments.uploadFile({
    teamId,
    headers: {
      "Content-Type": "application/octet-stream",
      "x-vercel-digest": fileSha,
      "Content-Length": fileBuffer.length.toString(),
    },
    body: fileBuffer,
  });

  // 2. Create deployment with the uploaded file
  const deployment = await vercel.deployments.createDeployment({
    teamId,
    requestBody: {
      files: [
        {
          file: ".vercel/source.tgz",
          sha: fileSha,
        },
      ],
      projectSettings: {
        framework: "nextjs",
      },
      name: `nextjs-deployment-${Date.now().toString(36)}`,
    },
  });

  return deployment;
}
```

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
Returns a deployment object upon successful creation.

#### Response Example
```json
{
  "id": "dpl_...";
  "name": "nextjs-deployment-...";
  "url": "some-url.vercel.app";
  // ... other deployment details
}
```
```

### On-Demand Revalidation (SvelteKit)

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/incremental-static-regeneration/quickstart

Trigger cache revalidation for SvelteKit ISR routes by sending a GET or HEAD request with a bypass token.

```APIDOC
## On-Demand Revalidation (SvelteKit)

### Description
Manually trigger cache revalidation for an ISR route in SvelteKit.

### Method
GET, HEAD

### Endpoint
`[your-route]`

### Parameters
#### Headers
- **x-prerender-revalidate** (string) - Required - The bypass token configured for the route.

### Request Example
```bash
x-prerender-revalidate: bypass_token_here
```

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
Indicates the request was processed.

#### Error Response (e.g., 401)
Indicates an invalid bypass token.

### Setup
1. Set an `BYPASS_TOKEN` Environment Variable with a secret value.
2. Assign your Environment Variable to the `bypassToken` config option for your SvelteKit route.
```

### Get Member Info using Vercel API (TypeScript)

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/integrations/create-integration/marketplace-api

This TypeScript function retrieves details about a specific team member associated with a Vercel installation. It makes a GET request to the Vercel API, requiring the installation ID and member ID. The response includes the member's ID, name, email, role, avatar, and creation timestamp. Proper error handling for the API request is included.

```typescript
async function getMemberInfo(
  installationId: string,
  memberId: string
): Promise<MemberInfo> {
  const response = await fetch(
    `https://api.vercel.com/v1/installations/${installationId}/member/${memberId}`,
    {
      headers: {
        'Authorization': `Bearer ${token}`,
      },
    }
  );

  if (!response.ok) {
    throw new Error(`Failed to get member info: ${response.statusText}`);
  }

  return response.json();
}
```

### GET /v1/installations/{integrationConfigurationId}/resources

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/rest-api/reference/endpoints/marketplace/get-integration-resources

Retrieves all resources for a given integration installation ID. This endpoint allows you to fetch details about connected services or configurations associated with a specific integration.

```APIDOC
## GET /v1/installations/{integrationConfigurationId}/resources

### Description
Get all resources for a given installation ID.

### Method
GET

### Endpoint
`/v1/installations/{integrationConfigurationId}/resources`

### Parameters
#### Path Parameters
- **integrationConfigurationId** (string) - Required - The unique identifier for the integration configuration.

#### Query Parameters
None

#### Request Body
None

### Request Example
```typescript
import { Vercel } from "@vercel/sdk";

const vercel = new Vercel({
  bearerToken: "YOUR_BEARER_TOKEN",
});

async function getResources() {
  const result = await vercel.marketplace.getIntegrationResources({
    integrationConfigurationId: "your_integration_configuration_id",
  });
  console.log(result);
}

getResources();
```

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
- **resources** (object[]) - Required - An array of resource objects.
  - **partnerId** (string) - The partner identifier.
  - **internalId** (string) - The internal identifier for the resource.
  - **name** (string) - The name of the resource.
  - **productId** (string) - The product identifier.
  - **status** (string) - The status of the resource (e.g., "ready").
  - **protocolSettings** (object) - Settings for the resource's protocol.
    - **experimentation** (object) - Experimentation settings.
      - **edgeConfigSyncingEnabled** (boolean) - Whether Edge Config syncing is enabled.
      - **edgeConfigId** (string) - The ID of the Edge Config.
      - **edgeConfigTokenId** (string) - The ID of the Edge Config token.
  - **notification** (object) - Notification details.
    - **level** (string) - The notification level (e.g., "error").
    - **title** (string) - The title of the notification.
    - **message** (string) - The message content of the notification.
    - **href** (string) - A URL for more information.
  - **billingPlanId** (string) - The billing plan identifier.
  - **metadata** (object) - Additional metadata for the resource.

#### Response Example
```json
{
  "resources": [
    {
      "partnerId": "",
      "internalId": "",
      "name": "",
      "productId": "",
      "status": "ready",
      "protocolSettings": {
        "experimentation": {
          "edgeConfigSyncingEnabled": true,
          "edgeConfigId": "",
          "edgeConfigTokenId": ""
        }
      },
      "notification": {
        "level": "error",
        "title": "",
        "message": "",
        "href": ""
      },
      "billingPlanId": "",
      "metadata": {}
    }
  ]
}
```

#### Authorizations
- Authorization: string header required
- Default authentication mechanism

### Node.js Script Example for Ignored Build Step

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/how-do-i-use-the-ignored-build-step-field-on-vercel

An example of how to use a Node.js script for the 'Ignored Build Step' field. This script checks the VERCEL_ENV and exits with 1 for production builds or 0 to skip. To use this, you would typically set the field to `node ignore-step.js` and ensure the script is in your repository. System environment variables must be exposed.

```javascript
const scriptArgs = process.argv.slice(2);
const ignoredBuildStepCommand = scriptArgs[0];

if (ignoredBuildStepCommand === 'node') {
  const nodeScript = scriptArgs[1];
  const env = process.env.VERCEL_ENV;

  if (env === 'production') {
    console.log('VERCEL_ENV:', env, '- Build can proceed.');
    process.exit(1); // Proceed with build
  } else {
    console.log('VERCEL_ENV:', env, '- Build cancelled.');
    process.exit(0); // Skip build
  }
} else {
  console.error('Invalid command or script.');
  process.exit(1);
}
```

### Get Member Information

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/integrations/create-integration/marketplace-api

Retrieves details about team members who have access to a specific installation. This is useful for access control, audit logs, or displaying member details within your integration.

```APIDOC
## Working with member information

### Description
Get details about team members who have access to an installation. Use this endpoint to retrieve member information for access control, audit logs, or displaying member details in your integration.

### Method
GET

### Endpoint
`/v1/installations/{installationId}/member/{memberId}`

### Parameters
#### Path Parameters
- **installationId** (string) - Required - The installation ID.
- **memberId** (string) - Required - The member ID.

### Request Example
```typescript
async function getMemberInfo(
  installationId: string,
  memberId: string,
  token: string
): Promise<any> {
  const response = await fetch(
    `https://api.vercel.com/v1/installations/${installationId}/member/${memberId}`,
    {
      headers: {
        'Authorization': `Bearer ${token}`,
      },
    }
  );

  if (!response.ok) {
    throw new Error(`Failed to get member info: ${response.statusText}`);
  }

  return response.json();
}
```

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
- **id** (string) - The unique identifier for the member.
- **name** (string) - The name of the member.
- **email** (string) - The email address of the member.
- **role** (string) - The role of the member within the installation (e.g., ADMIN, USER).
- **avatar** (string) - The URL of the member's avatar.
- **createdAt** (string) - The ISO 8601 timestamp when the member was created.

#### Response Example
```json
{
  "id": "member_abc123",
  "name": "John Doe",
  "email": "john@example.com",
  "role": "ADMIN",
  "avatar": "https://example.com/avatar.jpg",
  "createdAt": "2025-01-15T10:00:00Z"
}
```

### Member Roles
- `ADMIN` - Full access to the installation and its resources.
- `USER` - Limited access, can use resources but can't modify settings.
```

### Generate SHA for Vercel API File Upload

Source: https://context7_llms

This guide explains how to generate a SHA (Secure Hash Algorithm) necessary for uploading files to the Vercel API when creating a deployment. This is a fundamental step for programmatic deployments. The provided code examples show common methods for SHA generation.

```bash
FILE_PATH="./my-file.txt"
SHA=$(openssl dgst -sha1 -hex "$FILE_PATH" | awk '{print $2}')
echo "SHA: $SHA"
```

```javascript
const fs = require('fs');
const crypto = require('crypto');

const filePath = './my-file.txt';
const fileBuffer = fs.readFileSync(filePath);
const sha1Hash = crypto.createHash('sha1').update(fileBuffer).digest('hex');
console.log(`SHA: ${sha1Hash}`);
```

### Conditional redirect based on country header

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/project-configuration/vercel-ts

This example redirects requests not starting with `/uk/` to `/uk/:path*` if the `x-vercel-ip-country` header is `GB`, using a 307 Temporary Redirect. Requires `@vercel/config/v1`.

```typescript
import { routes, type VercelConfig } from '@vercel/config/v1';

export const config: VercelConfig = {
  redirects: [
    routes.redirect('/:path((?!uk/).*)', '/uk/:path*', {
      has: [
        {
          type: 'header',
          key: 'x-vercel-ip-country',
          value: 'GB',
        },
      ],
      permanent: false,
    }),
  ],
};
```

### On-Demand Revalidation API Route (Next.js - App Router)

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/incremental-static-regeneration/quickstart

Create an API route in Next.js (App Router) to handle on-demand revalidation by validating a secret token.

```APIDOC
## On-Demand Revalidation API Route (Next.js - App Router)

### Description
This API route allows you to trigger on-demand revalidation for specific paths in your Next.js application (App Router). It validates a secret token before revalidating the specified path.

### Method
GET

### Endpoint
`/api/revalidate`

### Query Parameters
- **secret** (string) - Required - A secret token to authenticate the revalidation request.

### Request Body
This endpoint does not use a request body.

### Request Example
```
GET /api/revalidate?secret=YOUR_SECRET_TOKEN
```

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
- **revalidated** (boolean) - `true` if the revalidation was successful.
- **now** (number) - The timestamp of the revalidation.

#### Response Example
```json
{
  "revalidated": true,
  "now": 1678886400000
}
```

#### Error Response (401)
- **message** (string) - 'Invalid credentials' if the secret does not match.

#### Error Response Example (401)
```
Invalid credentials
```

### Setup
1. Create an Environment Variable (e.g., `MY_SECRET_TOKEN`) to store your revalidation secret.
2. Implement the API route as shown in the code examples (JavaScript or TypeScript).
```

### Create Flags Discovery Endpoint (Next.js)

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/feature-flags/flags-explorer/getting-started

Implements the API endpoint for Next.js applications to expose feature flag definitions to Flags Explorer. It verifies access and returns provider data.

```typescript
import type { NextApiRequest, NextApiResponse } from 'next';
import { verifyAccess, version } from 'flags';
import { getProviderData } from 'flags/next';
import * as flags from '../../../flags';

export default async function handler(
  request: NextApiRequest,
  response: NextApiResponse,
) {
  const access = await verifyAccess(request.headers['authorization']);
  if (!access) return response.status(401).json(null);

  const apiData = getProviderData(flags);

  response.setHeader('x-flags-sdk-version', version);
  return response.json(apiData);
}
```

```javascript
import { verifyAccess, version } from 'flags';
import { getProviderData } from 'flags/next';
import * as flags from '../../../flags';

export default async function handler(request, response) {
  const access = await verifyAccess(request.headers['authorization']);
  if (!access) return response.status(401).json(null);

  const apiData = getProviderData(flags);

  response.setHeader('x-flags-sdk-version', version);
  return response.json(apiData);
}
```

### Deny Traffic from Specific IP Addresses with Vercel WAF API (JavaScript)

Source: https://context7_llms

Learn how to block specific IP addresses using the Vercel WAF API. This guide provides a JavaScript example for implementing IP-based access control, allowing you to deny traffic from a predefined list of malicious or unwanted IP addresses.

```javascript
import { NextResponse } from 'next/server';

// Example list of blocked IP addresses
const BLOCKED_IPS = new Set(['192.168.1.100', '10.0.0.5']);

export async function middleware(request) {
  const ip = request.ip;

  if (ip && BLOCKED_IPS.has(ip)) {
    // Block the request if the IP address is in the blocked list
    return new NextResponse('Access denied. Your IP address is blocked.', {
      status: 403,
      headers: {
        'X-Vercel-WAF-Block': 'true' // Custom header to indicate WAF action
      }
    });
  }

  // Allow the request to proceed if the IP is not blocked
  return NextResponse.next();
}
```

### Get Geolocation in Other Frameworks

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/routing-middleware/api

This example illustrates using the `geolocation()` helper function to retrieve request origin data, such as the country, in frameworks other than Next.js. It then redirects the user based on the country. Requires '@vercel/functions'.

```ts
import { geolocation } from '@vercel/functions';

const BLOCKED_COUNTRY = 'US';

export const config = {
  // Only run the middleware on the home route
  matcher: '/',
};

export default function middleware(request: Request) {
  const url = new URL(request.url);
  const { country } = geolocation(request);
  // You can also get the country using dot notation on the function
  // const country = geolocation(request).country;
  if (country === BLOCKED_COUNTRY) {
    url.pathname = '/blocked.html';
  } else {
    url.pathname = '/index.html';
  }
  // Return a new redirect response
  return Response.redirect(url);
}
```

```js
import { geolocation } from '@vercel/functions';

const BLOCKED_COUNTRY = 'US';

export const config = {
  // Only run the middleware on the home route
  matcher: '/',
};

export default function middleware(request) {
  const url = new URL(request.url);
  const { country } = geolocation(request);
  // You can also get the country using dot notation on the function
  // const country = geolocation(request).country;
  if (country === BLOCKED_COUNTRY) {
    url.pathname = '/blocked.html';
  } else {
    url.pathname = '/index.html';
  }
  // Return a new redirect response
  return Response.redirect(url);
}
```

### Deploy Storybook with Vercel (Conceptual)

Source: https://context7_llms

This guide provides instructions on deploying Storybook applications to Vercel. It covers the general process of building and hosting Storybook, allowing teams to showcase UI components in a centralized, accessible environment.

```plaintext
## Deploying Storybook to Vercel

Storybook can be deployed as a static site on Vercel, making your UI component library accessible to your team.

**Steps:**

1.  **Build Storybook:** Configure your project to build Storybook as static HTML. This is typically done by adding a build script to your `package.json`:
    ```json
    "scripts": {
      "build-storybook": "storybook build"
    }
    ```
    This command generates a `storybook-docs` or `dist` folder containing the static site.

2.  **Configure Vercel Build Settings:**
    *   **Build Command:** Set the Vercel build command to `npm run build-storybook` (or `yarn build-storybook`).
    *   **Output Directory:** Specify the output directory generated by the Storybook build command (e.g., `storybook-docs` or `dist`).

3.  **Deployment:** Connect your Git repository to Vercel. When you push changes, Vercel will automatically build and deploy your Storybook.

**Example `vercel.json` (Optional):**

If you need more advanced configuration, you can use `vercel.json`:

```json
{
  "framework": "custom",
  "rewrites": [
    { "source": "/((?!storybook-docs/).*)", "destination": "/index.html" } // Example for routing within Storybook
  ],
  "builds": [
    {
      "src": "./package.json",
      "use": "@vercel/static-build",
      "config": {
        "includeFiles": [
          "storybook-docs/**"
        ]
      }
    }
  ],
  "outputDirectory": "storybook-docs" // Or your specific output folder
}
```

Ensure your Storybook configuration (`.storybook/main.js`) is set up correctly for static builds.
```

### Custom Environments API

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/deployments/environments

Documentation for creating custom environments using the Vercel API, including cURL and SDK examples.

```APIDOC
## Creating a Custom Environment via API

Custom environments are useful for specialized workflows like `staging` or `QA`. Team owners and project admins can create, update, or remove these environments.

### Prerequisites

To interact with the Vercel API, you need an Authorization Bearer token. Refer to the [access token documentation](/docs/rest-api/reference/welcome#creating-an-access-token) for details on creating one.

### Using cURL

This example demonstrates how to create a custom environment using `curl`:

#### Method
POST

#### Endpoint
`/v9/projects/<project-id-or-name>/custom-environments`

#### Headers
- `Authorization: Bearer $VERCEL_TOKEN`
- `Content-Type: application/json`

#### Request Body
```json
{
  "slug": "<environment_name_slug>",
  "description": "<environment_description>"
}
```

#### Example
```bash
curl --request POST \
  --url https://api.vercel.com/v9/projects/<project-id-or-name>/custom-environments \
  --header "Authorization: Bearer $VERCEL_TOKEN" \
  --header "Content-Type: application/json" \
  --data '{ \
    "slug": "<environment_name_slug>", \
    "description": "<environment_description>" \
  }'
```

### Using the Vercel SDK (TypeScript)

This example shows how to create a custom environment using the Vercel SDK:

#### Method
`environment.createCustomEnvironment`

#### Parameters
- `idOrName` (string): The project ID or name.
- `requestBody` (object):
  - `slug` (string): The desired name slug for the environment.
  - `description` (string): An optional description for the environment.

#### Example
```typescript
import { Vercel } from '@vercel/sdk';

const vercel = new Vercel({
  bearerToken: '<YOUR_BEARER_TOKEN_HERE>',
});

async function run() {
  const result = await vercel.environment.createCustomEnvironment({
    idOrName: '<project-id-or-name>',
    requestBody: {
      slug: '<environment_name_slug>',
      description: '<environment_description>',
    },
  });
  // Handle the result
  console.log(result);
}

run();
```
```

### Upsert Installation API

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/integrations/create-integration/marketplace-api

An API endpoint used during the installation process to create or update an integration installation.

```APIDOC
## POST /integrations/installations

### Description
Creates or updates an installation of your integration. The response contains credentials, including an access token, needed for subsequent API calls to Vercel.

### Method
POST

### Endpoint
`/integrations/installations`

### Request Body
- **integrationId** (string) - Required - The ID of the integration.
- **installationId** (string) - Optional - The ID of the existing installation to update.
- **configuration** (object) - Optional - Configuration details for the installation.

### Request Example
```json
{
  "integrationId": "your-integration-id",
  "configuration": {
    "apiKey": "your-api-key"
  }
}
```

### Response
#### Success Response (200 or 201)
- **id** (string) - The installation ID.
- **integrationId** (string) - The ID of the integration.
- **credentials** (object) - Contains authentication details.
  - **accessToken** (string) - Bearer token for Vercel API calls.
  - **refreshToken** (string) - Token to refresh the access token.
- **configuration** (object) - The resolved configuration for the installation.

#### Response Example
```json
{
  "id": "install-12345",
  "integrationId": "your-integration-id",
  "credentials": {
    "accessToken": "your-vercel-access-token",
    "refreshToken": "your-vercel-refresh-token"
  },
  "configuration": {
    "apiKey": "your-api-key"
  }
}
```
```

### Build Weather API with FastAPI and Vercel

Source: https://context7_llms

This guide explains how to build a weather API using FastAPI, providing real-time weather data through a single route. The API is then prepared for deployment on Vercel.

```Python
from fastapi import FastAPI, HTTPException
from pydantic import BaseModel
import httpx
import os

app = FastAPI()

class WeatherData(BaseModel):
    city: str
    temperature: float
    description: str

WEATHER_API_KEY = os.environ.get("WEATHER_API_KEY")

@app.get("/api/weather", response_model=WeatherData)
async def get_weather(city: str):
    if not WEATHER_API_KEY:
        raise HTTPException(status_code=500, detail="Weather API key not configured")

    async with httpx.AsyncClient() as client:
        try:
            response = await client.get(
                f"https://api.openweathermap.org/data/2.5/weather?q={city}&appid={WEATHER_API_KEY}&units=metric"
            )
            response.raise_for_status()  # Raise an exception for bad status codes
            data = response.json()

            return WeatherData(
                city=data["name"],
                temperature=data["main"]["temp"],
                description=data["weather"][0]["description"],
            )
        except httpx.HTTPStatusError as exc:
            raise HTTPException(status_code=exc.response.status_code, detail=f"Error response {exc.response.status_code} while requesting {exc.request.url!r} - {exc.response.text}")
        except Exception as e:
            raise HTTPException(status_code=500, detail=f"An error occurred: {str(e)}")

# To deploy on Vercel, save this as main.py and ensure WEATHER_API_KEY is set in Vercel environment variables.
# You will also need a vercel.json file to specify the ASGI app:
# {
#   "version": 2,
#   "builds": [
#     {
#       "src": "main.py",
#       "use": "@vercel/python"
#     }
#   ],
#   "routes": [
#     {
#       "src": "/.*",
#       "dest": "/main.py"
#     }
#   ]
# }
```

### Delete Headers Starting with a Prefix

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/project-configuration/vercel-json

This example demonstrates deleting any incoming request header that begins with the prefix 'x-react-router-' for all requests to the '/home' route. It uses the 'request.headers' transform type with the 'delete' operation and a 'pre' condition within the target key.

```json
{
  "$schema": "https://openapi.vercel.sh/vercel.json",
  "routes": [
    {
      "src": "/home",
      "transforms": [
        {
          "type": "request.headers",
          "op": "delete",
          "target": {
            "key": {
              "pre": "x-react-router-"
            }
          }
        }
      ]
    }
  ]
}
```

### Database Comparison: MySQL, PostgreSQL, MongoDB

Source: https://context7_llms

This guide provides a comparison between MySQL, PostgreSQL, and MongoDB, focusing on aspects relevant to Vercel deployments. It covers data types, indexing, concurrency, scalability, replication, and ACID compliance to aid in selecting the optimal database for your application.

```plaintext
## Database Comparison: MySQL vs. PostgreSQL vs. MongoDB

**Key Considerations:**

*   **Data Model:**
    *   MySQL & PostgreSQL: Relational (SQL)
    *   MongoDB: Document (NoSQL)
*   **Schema:**
    *   MySQL & PostgreSQL: Strict schema (defined beforehand)
    *   MongoDB: Flexible schema (dynamic)
*   **Scalability:**
    *   MySQL & PostgreSQL: Vertical scaling primarily, horizontal scaling possible but complex.
    *   MongoDB: Horizontal scaling (sharding) is a core feature.
*   **ACID Compliance:**
    *   MySQL & PostgreSQL: Strong ACID compliance.
    *   MongoDB: ACID compliance for single documents, multi-document transactions improved in recent versions.
*   **Use Cases:**
    *   MySQL/PostgreSQL: Complex queries, structured data, transactional integrity.
    *   MongoDB: Rapid development, unstructured/semi-structured data, high read/write throughput.
```

### Configure Middleware Path Matching (TypeScript)

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/routing-middleware/getting-started

This example illustrates how to configure the Routing Middleware to run only on specific paths using the `matcher` configuration. It includes a regex to exclude static files and shows examples of more specific path patterns.

```typescript
export default function middleware(request: Request) {
  const url = new URL(request.url);

  // Only handle specific redirects
  if (url.pathname === '/old-blog') {
    return new Response(null, {
      status: 302,
      headers: { Location: '/blog' },
    });
  }

  return new Response('Middleware processed this request');
}

// Configure which paths trigger the Middleware
export const config = {
  matcher: [
    // Run on all paths except static files
    '/((?!_next/static|_next/image|favicon.ico).*)',
    // Or be more specific:
    // '/blog/:path*',
    // '/api/:path*'
  ],
};
```

### Configure Next.js Rewrites for Vercel Flags API

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/feature-flags/flags-explorer/getting-started

This configuration snippet for `next.config.js` sets up a rewrite rule. It's necessary for the Pages Router in Next.js to correctly route requests to the Vercel flags API, as API routes must be within the `api` folder. This ensures that the source path `/.well-known/vercel/flags` is mapped to the destination `api/vercel/flags`.

```javascript
module.exports = {
  async rewrites() {
    return [
      {
        source: '/.well-known/vercel/flags',
        destination: '/api/vercel/flags',
      },
    ];
  },
};
```

### Get Request IP Address using Vercel Functions

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/routing-middleware/api

Retrieves the IP address of the incoming request from headers. It supports different frameworks like Next.js and other custom setups. The function returns the IP address or undefined if not found.

```typescript
import { ipAddress } from '@vercel/functions';
import { next } from '@vercel/functions';

export default function middleware(request: Request) {
  const ip = ipAddress(request);
  return next({
    headers: { 'x-your-ip-address': ip || 'unknown' },
  });
}
```

```javascript
import { ipAddress } from '@vercel/functions';

### Set up Deploy Hooks with Vercel and Headless CMS

Source: https://context7_llms

This guide explains how to create custom Deploy Hooks in Vercel to trigger automatic deployments when changes occur in a Headless CMS. This automation ensures that your website content is always up-to-date. The process involves creating a webhook in your Headless CMS that points to a Vercel Deploy Hook URL, which then initiates a new build and deployment on Vercel.

```bash
# Example using cURL to create a deploy hook via Vercel CLI or API
# Replace YOUR_VERCEL_TOKEN and YOUR_PROJECT_ID with your actual values

VERCEL_TOKEN="YOUR_VERCEL_TOKEN"
PROJECT_ID="YOUR_PROJECT_ID"
BRANCH="main"

curl -X POST "https://api.vercel.com/v1/projects/$PROJECT_ID/hooks" \
     -H "Authorization: Bearer $VERCEL_TOKEN" \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
     -d "{\"name\": \"cms-update-hook\", \"type\": \"benzoimidazol\", \"data\": { \"branch\": \"$BRANCH\" }}"
```

### Deploy Button Installation Flow Query Parameters

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/integrations/create-integration/submit-integration

These query parameters are used when a user installs the integration via the Vercel deploy button.

```APIDOC
## GET /deploy-button-callback

### Description
This endpoint is the callback URL for installations initiated using the Vercel deploy button. It handles post-installation redirects and configuration updates.

### Method
GET

### Endpoint
/deploy-button-callback

### Query Parameters
- **code** (string) - Required - The code you received.
- **teamId** (string) - Optional - The ID of the team (only if a team is selected).
- **configurationId** (string) - Optional - The ID of the configuration. If the integration is already installed, this will be the most recent `configurationId`.
- **next** (string) - Required - Encoded URL to redirect to, once the installation process on your side is finished.
- **currentProjectId** (string) - Optional - The ID of the created project.
- **external-id** (string) - Optional - Reference of your choice. See [External ID](/docs/deploy-button/callback#external-id) for more details.
- **source** (string) - Optional - Source defines where the integration was installed from (e.g., `deploy-button`).

### Request Example
```json
{
  "example": "?code=jMIukZ1DBCKXHje3X14BCkU0&teamId=team_LLHUOMOoDlqOp8wPE4kFo9pE&configurationId=icfg_6uKSUQ359QCbPfECTAY9murE&next=https%3A%2F%2Fvercel.com%2F...&currentProjectId=QmXGTs7mvAMMC7WW5ebrM33qKG32QK3h4vmQMjmY&external-id=1284210&source=deploy-button"
}
```

### Response
#### Success Response (302 Found)
- Description: Redirects the user to the provided `next` URL after installation or update.

#### Response Example
```json
{
  "example": "Redirect to: https://your-domain.com/callback?code=...&configurationId=..."
}
```

### Notes
- Ensure to store the `configurationId` along with an access token. If an existing `configurationId` is passed, retrieve the corresponding access token.
```

### Initialize Statsig with Edge Config in Next.js Middleware (JavaScript)

import Statsig from 'statsig-node';
import { createClient } from '@vercel/edge-config';

};

});

export async function middleware() {

}

## Marketplace Installation Flow

This flow describes the process for installations initiated from the Vercel Marketplace.

After a user installs the integration from the Vercel Marketplace, they are redirected to a page on your side to complete the setup.

Once the setup is finished on your end, redirect the user to the provided `next` URL to close the popup and continue the process.

These query parameters are appended to the redirection URL after a marketplace installation:

- **configurationId** (string) - Optional - The ID of the configuration associated with the installation.
- **next** (string) - Required - An encoded URL to redirect to after the installation process on your side is completed.
- **source** (string) - Optional - Indicates the source from which the integration was installed (e.g., `marketplace`).

#### Example

`https://your-redirect-url.com/?code=jMIukZ1DBCKXHje3X14BCkU0&teamId=team_LLHUOMOoDlqOp8wPE4kFo9pE&configurationId=icfg_6uKSUQ359QCbPfECTAY9murE&next=https%3A%2F%2Fvercel.com%2F...&source=marketplace`

### POST /v1/chat/completions with Provider Options

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/ai-gateway/openai-compat

This example shows how to use the `providerOptions` to specify the order in which different AI providers should be tried for completions.

```APIDOC
## POST /v1/chat/completions with Provider Options

### Description
This endpoint allows for chat completions and offers advanced configuration via `providerOptions`. Specifically, the `gateway.order` option enables you to define a fallback strategy for AI providers, ensuring that if the primary provider fails or is unavailable, a secondary provider (or more) is attempted in the specified order.

### Method
POST

### Endpoint
/v1/chat/completions

### Parameters
#### Request Body
- **model** (string) - Required - The identifier of the model to use for completions.
- **messages** (array) - Required - A list of message objects representing the conversation history.
  - **role** (string) - Required - The role of the message sender (e.g., 'user', 'assistant', 'system').
  - **content** (string) - Required - The content of the message.
- **stream** (boolean) - Optional - Whether to stream the response. Defaults to false.
- **providerOptions** (object) - Optional - Configuration for selecting AI providers.
  - **gateway** (object) - Gateway-specific options.
    - **order** (array) - Optional - An array of strings specifying the preferred order of AI providers to use (e.g., ['vertex', 'anthropic']). The gateway will attempt to use providers in this order.

### Request Example
```json
{
  "model": "anthropic/claude-sonnet-4",
  "messages": [
    {
      "role": "user",
      "content": "Tell me the history of the San Francisco Mission-style burrito in two paragraphs."
    }
  ],
  "stream": false,
  "providerOptions": {
    "gateway": {
      "order": ["vertex", "anthropic"]
    }
  }
}
```

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
- **id** (string) - Unique identifier for the completion.
- **type** (string) - The type of the response, e.g., 'chat_completion'.
- **role** (string) - The role of the assistant in the conversation.
- **content** (string) - The text content of the assistant's reply.
- **model** (string) - The identifier of the model used.
- **stop_reason** (string) - The reason the model stopped generating output.
- **usage** (object) - Information about token usage.
  - **prompt_tokens** (integer) - Number of tokens in the prompt.
  - **completion_tokens** (integer) - Number of tokens in the completion.
  - **total_tokens** (integer) - Total tokens used.

#### Response Example
```json
{
  "id": "chatcmpl-456",
  "type": "chat_completion",
  "role": "assistant",
  "content": "The Mission-style burrito originated in the Mission District of San Francisco in the 1960s. It is characterized by its large size, wrapped tightly in a steamed tortilla, and typically includes rice, beans, meat, salsa, and cheese. Its invention is often attributed to various taquerias in the neighborhood seeking to offer a substantial and portable meal.",
  "model": "anthropic/claude-sonnet-4",
  "stop_reason": "end_turn",
  "usage": {
    "prompt_tokens": 50,
    "completion_tokens": 75,
    "total_tokens": 125
  }
}
```
```

### Advanced vercel.ts Configuration Example

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/project-configuration/vercel-ts

Demonstrates advanced configuration using vercel.ts, including build commands, framework settings, dynamic rewrites with API calls and environment variables, redirects, headers with caching, and cron jobs.

```typescript
import { routes, deploymentEnv, type VercelConfig } from '@vercel/config/v1';

export const config: VercelConfig = {
  buildCommand: 'npm run build',
  framework: 'nextjs',

  rewrites: [
    routes.rewrite('/api/(.*)', 'https://backend.api.example.com/$1'),
    routes.rewrite('/(.*)', 'https://api.example.com/$1', {
      requestHeaders: {
        authorization: `Bearer ${deploymentEnv('API_TOKEN')}`,
      },
    }),
    routes.rewrite(
      '/users/:userId/posts/:postId',
      'https://api.example.com/users/$1/posts/$2',
      ({ userId, postId }) => ({
        requestHeaders: {
          'x-user-id': userId,
          'x-post-id': postId,
          authorization: `Bearer ${deploymentEnv('API_KEY')}`,
        },
      }),
    ),
  ],

  redirects: [routes.redirect('/old-docs', '/docs', { permanent: true })],

  headers: [
    routes.cacheControl('/static/(.*)', {
      public: true,
      maxAge: '1 week',
      immutable: true,
    }),
  ],

  crons: [{ path: '/api/cleanup', schedule: '0 0 * * *' }],
};
```

### Next.js Pages Router: Fetch and Render Blog Posts with ISR (JavaScript)

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/incremental-static-regeneration/quickstart

This snippet demonstrates fetching blog posts from an API and rendering them in a Next.js application using the Pages Router. It configures Incremental Static Regeneration (ISR) with a revalidation interval of 10 seconds. It uses plain JavaScript.

```javascript
export async function getStaticProps() {
  const res = await fetch('https://api.vercel.app/blog');
  const posts = await res.json();

  return {
    props: {
      posts,
    },
    revalidate: 10,
  };
}

export default function BlogPosts({ posts }) {
  return (
    <ul>
      {posts.map((post) => (
        <li key={post.id}>{post.title}</li>
      ))}
    </ul>
  );
}
```

### Get and Set Cache Entries with TTL and Tags (TypeScript)

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/functions/functions-api-reference/vercel-functions-package

Demonstrates how to retrieve a value from the Vercel Runtime Cache using `cache.get()` and store a new value with a specified TTL and tags using `cache.set()`. This example fetches data from an external API if the cache is missed and then caches the result.

```typescript
import { getCache } from '@vercel/functions';

export default {
  async fetch(request) {
    const cache = getCache();

    // Get a value from cache
    const value = await cache.get('somekey');

    if (value) {
      return new Response(JSON.stringify(value));
    }

    const res = await fetch('https://api.vercel.app/blog');
    const originValue = await res.json();

    // Set a value in cache with TTL and tags
    await cache.set('somekey', originValue, {
      ttl: 3600, // 1 hour in seconds
      tags: ['example-tag'],
    });

    return new Response(JSON.stringify(originValue));
  },
};
```

### Deploy Real-Time Apps with Pusher Channels on Vercel (JavaScript)

Source: https://context7_llms

This guide explains how to build and deploy real-time applications using Pusher Channels on Vercel. It covers the necessary client-side and server-side configurations to enable real-time communication features.

```javascript
// Client-side example (e.g., in a React component)
import Pusher from 'pusher-js';
import React, { useEffect } from 'react';

function RealTimeComponent() {
  useEffect(() => {
    // Initialize Pusher
    Pusher.logToConsole = true; // Enable logging for debugging

    const pusher = new Pusher('YOUR_APP_KEY', {
      cluster: 'YOUR_APP_CLUSTER',
    });

    const channel = pusher.subscribe('my-channel'); // Subscribe to a channel

    // Bind to an event
    channel.bind('my-event', function(data) {
      console.log('Received event:', data);
      // Update UI or perform actions based on received data
    });

    // Clean up subscription on component unmount
    return () => {
      pusher.unsubscribe('my-channel');
    };
  }, []);

  return (
    <div>
      <h1>Real-Time Updates</h1>
      <p>Check the console for messages from Pusher.</p>
    </div>
  );
}

export default RealTimeComponent;

// Server-side example (e.g., Node.js API route or backend service)
// You would use the pusher package to trigger events
/*
const Pusher = require('pusher');

const pusher = new Pusher({
  appId: "YOUR_APP_ID",
  key: "YOUR_APP_KEY",
  secret: "YOUR_APP_SECRET",
  cluster: "YOUR_APP_CLUSTER",
  useTLS: true
});

// Example of triggering an event
function triggerMyEvent(data) {
  pusher.trigger('my-channel', 'my-event', data);
}

triggerMyEvent({ message: 'Hello from the server!' });
*/

```

### Get Deployment Build Logs

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/mcp/vercel-mcp/tools

Gets the build logs of a deployment by deployment ID or URL. Can be used to investigate why a deployment failed.

```APIDOC
## POST /llmstxt/vercel_llms_txt/get_deployment_build_logs

### Description
Get the build logs of a deployment by deployment ID or URL. Can be used to investigate why a deployment failed.

### Method
POST

### Endpoint
/llmstxt/vercel_llms_txt/get_deployment_build_logs

### Parameters
#### Query Parameters
- **idOrUrl** (string) - Required - The unique identifier or hostname of the deployment
- **limit** (number) - Optional - Maximum number of log lines to return. Defaults to 100.
- **teamId** (string) - Required - The team ID to get the deployment events for. Alternatively the team slug can be used.

### Request Example
```json
{
  "idOrUrl": "dpl_abc123",
  "teamId": "team_abc",
  "limit": 50
}
```

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
- **logs** (array) - Array of log lines
  - **line** (string) - A single log line
  - **type** (string) - The type of log (e.g., "stdout", "stderr")
  - **timestamp** (number) - Timestamp of the log entry

#### Response Example
```json
{
  "logs": [
    {
      "line": "Build step completed successfully.",
      "type": "stdout",
      "timestamp": 1678886500
    }
  ]
}
```

### Checkout Form Component for Stripe Redirect (TypeScript)

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/getting-started-with-nextjs-typescript-stripe

This React component, written in TypeScript, handles the user submission for donations. It calls the checkout_sessions API route to create a CheckoutSession and then uses Stripe.js to redirect the user to the Stripe Checkout page.

```typescript
// Partial of ./components/CheckoutForm.tsx
// ...
const handleSubmit = async (e: FormEvent) => {
  e.preventDefault();

  // Create a Checkout Session.
  const checkoutSession: Stripe.Checkout.Session = await fetchPostJSON(
    '/api/checkout_sessions',
    { amount: input.customDonation }
  );

  if ((checkoutSession as any).statusCode === 500) {
    console.error((checkoutSession as any).message);
    return;
  }

  // Redirect to Checkout.
  const stripe = await getStripe();
  const { error } = await stripe!.redirectToCheckout({
    // Make the id field from the Checkout Session creation API response
    // available to this file, so you can provide it as parameter here
    // instead of the {{CHECKOUT_SESSION_ID}} placeholder.
    sessionId: checkoutSession.id,
  });

  // If `redirectToCheckout` fails due to a browser or network
  // error, display the localized error message to your customer
  // using `error.message`.
  console.warn(error.message);
};
// ...
```

### Preview Environment Overview

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/deployments/environments

Information about Vercel's Preview environments, how they are triggered, and the types of URLs they provide.

```APIDOC
## Preview Environment (Pre-production)

**Preview** environments enable you to deploy and test changes in a live setting without affecting your production site. Vercel automatically creates a preview deployment in the following scenarios:

- Pushing a commit to a branch that is not your production branch (e.g., `main`).
- Creating a pull request (PR) on GitHub, GitLab, or Bitbucket.
- Deploying using the CLI without the `-prod` flag (e.g., `vercel`).

Each preview deployment receives an automatically generated URL, which are often found in Git provider PR comments or the Vercel Dashboard. There are two types of preview URLs:

- **Branch-specific URL**: Consistently points to the latest changes on a specific branch.
- **Commit-specific URL**: Points to the exact deployment of a particular commit.

Refer to [generated URLs](/docs/deployments/generated-urls) for more details.
```

### Create Stripe CheckoutSession API Route (TypeScript)

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/getting-started-with-nextjs-typescript-stripe

This TypeScript API route creates a Stripe CheckoutSession. It takes donation amount and currency from the request body and configures success/cancel URLs. The session ID is returned to initiate the Stripe redirect.

```typescript
// Partial of ./pages/api/checkout_sessions/index.ts

// Create Checkout Sessions from body params.
const params: Stripe.Checkout.SessionCreateParams = {
  submit_type: 'donate',
  payment_method_types: ['card'],
  line_items: [
    {
      name: 'Custom amount donation',
      amount: formatAmountForStripe(amount, CURRENCY),
      currency: CURRENCY,
      quantity: 1,
    },
  ],
  success_url: `${req.headers.origin}/result?session_id={CHECKOUT_SESSION_ID}`,
  cancel_url: `${req.headers.origin}/result?session_id={CHECKOUT_SESSION_ID}`,
};
const checkoutSession: Stripe.Checkout.Session = await stripe.checkout.sessions.create(params);
// ...
```

### Get Raw Body of Vercel Serverless Function

Source: https://context7_llms

This snippet shows how to retrieve the raw body of a POST request within a Vercel Serverless Function. By disabling default body parsing, you can access the raw request data, which is useful for handling specific content types or custom parsing logic. This example uses Node.js.

```javascript
export default async function handler(req, res) {
  if (req.method === 'POST') {
    let rawBody = '';
    req.on('data', (chunk) => {
      rawBody += chunk.toString(); // convert Buffer to string
    });
    req.on('end', () => {
      console.log('Raw Body:', rawBody);
      res.status(200).json({ message: 'Raw body received', body: rawBody });
    });
  } else {
    res.setHeader('Allow', ['POST']);
    res.status(405).end(`Method ${req.method} Not Allowed`);
  }
}
```

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/vercel-blob/examples

This snippet demonstrates a periodic backup of Vercel Blob storage to AWS S3 using a Cron Job. It utilizes the Vercel Blob SDK to list blobs and streams the content directly to S3 using the AWS SDK. This approach avoids buffering large files in memory. Ensure you have `node:stream`, `@aws-sdk/client-s3`, `@vercel/blob`, and `@aws-sdk/lib-storage` installed.

```typescript
import { Readable } from 'node:stream';
import { S3Client } from '@aws-sdk/client-s3';
import { list } from '@vercel/blob';
import { Upload } from '@aws-sdk/lib-storage';
import type { NextRequest } from 'next/server';
import type { ReadableStream } from 'node:stream/web';

export async function GET(request: NextRequest) {
  const authHeader = request.headers.get('authorization');
  if (authHeader !== `Bearer ${process.env.CRON_SECRET}`) {
    return new Response('Unauthorized',
      {
        status: 401,
      }
    );
  }

  const s3 = new S3Client({
    region: 'us-east-1',
  });

  let cursor: string | undefined;

  do {
    const listResult = await list({
      cursor,
      limit: 250,
    });

    if (listResult.blobs.length > 0) {
      await Promise.all(
        listResult.blobs.map(async (blob) => {
          const res = await fetch(blob.url);
          if (res.body) {
            const parallelUploads3 = new Upload({
              client: s3,
              params: {
                Bucket: 'vercel-blob-backup',
                Key: blob.pathname,
                Body: Readable.fromWeb(res.body as ReadableStream),
              },
              leavePartsOnError: false,
            });

            await parallelUploads3.done();
          }
        })
      );
    }

    cursor = listResult.cursor;
  } while (cursor);

  return new Response('Backup done!');
}
```

### List Blobs and Generate Download Links with Vercel Blob SDK

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/vercel-blob

This example shows how to retrieve a list of blobs stored in Vercel Blob and render them as download links. It uses the `list` function from `@vercel/blob` to fetch blob data. For each blob, it maps over the `blobs` array to create anchor tags (`<a>`) using the `blob.downloadUrl` property, which guarantees a file download.

```javascript
import { list } from '@vercel/blob';

export default async function Page() {
  const response = await list();

  return (
    <>
      {response.blobs.map((blob) => (
        <a key={blob.pathname} href={blob.downloadUrl}>
          {blob.pathname}
        </a>
      ))}
    </>
  );
}
```

### Next.js Route Handler (App Router) CORS Configuration

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/how-to-enable-cors

Configure CORS headers for a Next.js App Router route handler. This example sets up OPTIONS and GET request handlers to manage cross-origin access, specifying allowed origins, methods, and headers. It dynamically sets the origin based on the environment.

```javascript
const ALLOWED_ORIGIN = process.env.NODE_ENV === 'production' ? 'https://app.example' : '*';

export async function OPTIONS() {
  return new Response(null, {
    status: 200,
    headers: {
      'Access-Control-Allow-Origin': ALLOWED_ORIGIN,
      'Access-Control-Allow-Methods': 'GET, POST, OPTIONS',
      'Access-Control-Allow-Headers': 'Content-Type, Authorization',
      'Access-Control-Allow-Credentials': 'true',
    },
  });
}

export async function GET() {
  return Response.json({ ok: true }, {
    headers: {
      'Access-Control-Allow-Origin': ALLOWED_ORIGIN,
    },
  });
}
```
