### Build Weather API with Nitro and Vercel

Source: https://context7_llms

This guide explains how to build a weather API using Nitro, leveraging Vercel's cache storage and Observability features. It focuses on creating a single Nitro route to provide real-time weather data.

```JavaScript
// Example using Nitro server routes
// Create a file like: ./server/api/weather.js

import { defineEventHandler, H3Event } from 'h3';
import fetch from 'node-fetch';

const WEATHER_API_KEY = process.env.WEATHER_API_KEY;

export default defineEventHandler(async (event: H3Event) => {
  const queryParams = new URLSearchParams(event.req.url?.split('?')[1] || '');
  const city = queryParams.get('city');

  if (!city) {
    event.res.statusCode = 400;
    return { error: 'City parameter is required' };
  }

  if (!WEATHER_API_KEY) {
    event.res.statusCode = 500;
    return { error: 'Weather API key not configured' };
  }

  try {
    const response = await fetch(`https://api.openweathermap.org/data/2.5/weather?q=${city}&appid=${WEATHER_API_KEY}&units=metric`);
    const data = await response.json();

    if (data.cod !== 200) {
      event.res.statusCode = data.cod;
      return { error: data.message };
    }

    // Example of using Vercel cache (requires @vercel/kv)
    // await setKV('weather:' + city, data, { ex: 3600 }); // Cache for 1 hour

    return {
      city: data.name,
      temperature: data.main.temp,
      description: data.weather[0].description,
    };
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error fetching weather data:', error);
    event.res.statusCode = 500;
    return { error: 'Failed to fetch weather data' };
  }
});

// To deploy on Vercel, ensure you have a nitro.config.ts or similar setup
// and the WEATHER_API_KEY environment variable is set.
```

### Get Vercel OIDC Token for Azure Cosmos DB (TypeScript)

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/functions/functions-api-reference/vercel-functions-package

The `getVercelOidcToken` function retrieves the OIDC token from either the environment variable `VERCEL_OIDC_TOKEN` or request context headers. This token can then be used with Azure SDKs to authenticate with services like Cosmos DB. This example demonstrates setting up a `CosmosClient` using the retrieved OIDC token.

```typescript
import { ClientAssertionCredential } from '@azure/identity';
import { CosmosClient } from '@azure/cosmos';
import { getVercelOidcToken } from '@vercel/oidc';

const credentialsProvider = new ClientAssertionCredential(
  process.env.AZURE_TENANT_ID,
  process.env.AZURE_CLIENT_ID,
  getVercelOidcToken,
);

const cosmosClient = new CosmosClient({
  endpoint: process.env.COSMOS_DB_ENDPOINT,
  aadCredentials: credentialsProvider,
});

export const GET = () => {
  const container = cosmosClient
    .database(process.env.COSMOS_DB_NAME)
    .container(process.env.COSMOS_DB_CONTAINER);
  const items = await container.items.query('SELECT * FROM f').fetchAll();
  return Response.json({ items: items.resources });
};
```

### Update Installation Notification with TypeScript

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/integrations/create-integration/marketplace-api

Updates the notification field for a Vercel installation using the PATCH /v1/installations/{installationId} endpoint. This function requires an installation ID and a notification object containing title, message, and optional href and type. It handles potential API errors and returns the updated installation data.

```typescript
interface Notification {
  title: string;
  message: string;
  href?: string;
  type?: 'info' | 'warning' | 'error';
}

async function updateInstallationNotification(
  installationId: string,
  notification: Notification
) {
  const response = await fetch(
    `https://api.vercel.com/v1/installations/${installationId}`,
    {
      method: 'PATCH',
      headers: {
        'Authorization': `Bearer ${token}`,
        'Content-Type': 'application/json',
      },
      body: JSON.stringify({ notification }),
    }
  );

  if (!response.ok) {
    throw new Error(`Failed to update notification: ${response.statusText}`);
  }

  return response.json();
}

// Example usage with regular URL:
await updateInstallationNotification('icfg_abc123', {
  title: 'Action Required',
  message: 'Please complete your account setup',
  href: 'https://your-integration.com/setup',
  type: 'warning',
});

// Or with SSO-enabled URL for authenticated access:
// href: 'sso:https://your-integration.com/setup',
```

### Verify Stripe Webhook Event Signature in Next.js

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/getting-started-with-nextjs-typescript-stripe

This code demonstrates how to verify the signature of incoming Stripe webhook events in a Next.js API route. It disables the default body parser, reads the raw request body, retrieves the signature from headers, and uses `stripe.webhooks.constructEvent` to validate the event against your webhook secret. Errors during verification are logged and returned to the client.

```typescript
// Partial of ./pages/api/webhooks/index.ts
// ...

const webhookSecret: string = process.env.STRIPE_WEBHOOK_SECRET!

// Stripe requires the raw body to construct the event.
export const config = {
  api: {
    bodyParser: false,
  },
}

const webhookHandler = async (req: NextApiRequest, res: NextApiResponse) => {
  if (req.method === 'POST') {
    const buf = await buffer(req)
    const sig = req.headers['stripe-signature']!
    let event: Stripe.Event

    try {
      event = stripe.webhooks.constructEvent(buf.toString(), sig, webhookSecret)
    } catch (err) {
      // On error, log and return the error message
      console.log(`âŒ Error message: ${err.message}`)
      res.status(400).send(`Webhook Error: ${err.message}`)
      return
    }

    // Successfully constructed event
    console.log('âœ… Success:', event.id)
    // ...
  }
}
```

### Register Domain to Team Vercel Account using Curl

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/how-do-i-add-a-domain-using-the-vercel-api

This example shows how to add a domain to a Vercel team account using `curl`. It involves two steps: first obtaining the team ID via a GET request, and then using that team ID in the POST request to register the domain. Replace 'TOKEN' and 'TEAM_ID' with your actual Vercel API token and the team ID.

```shell
curl "https://api.vercel.com/v1/teams"
 -H "Authorization: Bearer TOKEN"
```

```shell
curl -X POST "https://api.vercel.com/v4/domains?teamId=TEAM_ID" \
 -H "Authorization: Bearer TOKEN" \
 -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
 -d '{ "name": "example.com" }'
```

### Get Deployment

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/mcp/vercel-mcp/tools

Retrieves detailed information for a specific deployment, including build status, regions, and metadata.

```APIDOC
## POST /llmstxt/vercel_llms_txt/get_deployment

### Description
Retrieve detailed information for a specific deployment including build status, regions, and metadata.

### Method
POST

### Endpoint
/llmstxt/vercel_llms_txt/get_deployment

### Parameters
#### Query Parameters
- **idOrUrl** (string) - Required - The unique identifier or hostname of the deployment
- **teamId** (string) - Required - The team ID to get the deployment events for. Alternatively the team slug can be used.

### Request Example
```json
{
  "idOrUrl": "dpl_abc123",
  "teamId": "team_abc"
}
```

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
- **deployment** (object) - Detailed deployment information
  - **id** (string) - The deployment ID
  - **url** (string) - The deployment URL
  - **name** (string) - The deployment name
  - **region** (string) - The deployment region
  - **createdAt** (number) - Timestamp of creation
  - **build** (object) - Build details
    - **status** (string) - Build status

#### Response Example
```json
{
  "deployment": {
    "id": "dpl_abc123",
    "url": "my-project-abc.vercel.app",
    "name": "my-project",
    "region": "us-east-1",
    "createdAt": 1678886400,
    "build": {
      "status": "COMPLETED"
    }
  }
}
```
```

### Stream AI Model Response with AI SDK

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/ai-gateway/getting-started

This TypeScript code snippet shows how to make an AI model request using the AI SDK's streamText function. It imports necessary modules, defines an async main function to handle the request, streams the text response, and logs token usage and finish reason. It requires dotenv/config for environment variable loading.

```typescript
import { streamText } from 'ai';
import 'dotenv/config';

async function main() {
  const result = streamText({
    model: 'openai/gpt-5',
    prompt: 'Invent a new holiday and describe its traditions.',
  });

  for await (const textPart of result.textStream) {
    process.stdout.write(textPart);
  }

  console.log();
  console.log('Token usage:', await result.usage);
  console.log('Finish reason:', await result.finishReason);
}

main().catch(console.error);
```

### Optimize Images with Imagemin

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/troubleshooting-sigkill-out-of-memory-errors

Integrate image compression into your build process using the 'imagemin' library. This allows for automatic optimization of various image formats (JPEG, PNG, SVG, etc.) to reduce file sizes and memory consumption during builds. Ensure the necessary plugins for your image types are installed.

```javascript
const imagemin = require('imagemin');
const imageminJpeg = require('imagemin-jpeg-recompress');
const imageminPng = require('imagemin-pngquant');

(async () => {
	const files = await imagemin(['images/*.{jpg,png}'], {
		destination: 'build/images',
		plugins: [
			imageminJpeg({ 
				quality: '65-80'
			}),
			imageminPng({
				quality: [0.6, 0.8]
			})
		]
	});

	console.log(files.length + ' images optimized.');
})();
```

### GitLab CI/CD Configuration for Vercel Deployments

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/how-can-i-use-gitlab-pipelines-with-vercel

This configuration defines two stages: 'deploy_preview' for creating preview deployments on commits except to the 'main' branch, and 'deploy_production' for creating production deployments on commits to the 'main' branch. It uses the Node.js 22 image, installs the Vercel CLI, pulls project settings, builds the project, and deploys using `vercel deploy --prebuilt`.

```yaml
default:
  image: node:22

deploy_preview:
  stage: deploy
  except:
    - main
  script:
    - npm install --global vercel
    - vercel pull --yes --environment=preview --token=$VERCEL_TOKEN
    - vercel build --token=$VERCEL_TOKEN
    - vercel deploy --prebuilt --token=$VERCEL_TOKEN

deploy_production:
  stage: deploy
  only:
    - main
  script:
    - npm install --global vercel
    - vercel pull --yes --environment=production --token=$VERCEL_TOKEN
    - vercel build --prod --token=$VERCEL_TOKEN
    - vercel deploy --prebuilt --prod --token=$VERCEL_TOKEN
```

### Retrieve Vercel OIDC Token with getVercelOidcToken

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/oidc/api

This TypeScript code example demonstrates how to use the `getVercelOidcToken` function from the `@vercel/oidc` package to obtain a Vercel OIDC token within a Vercel Serverless Function. The retrieved token can then be used to authenticate requests to external APIs. This example shows how to fetch data from an example API, including the OIDC token in the Authorization header.

```typescript
import { getVercelOidcToken } from '@vercel/oidc';

export const GET = async () => {
  const result = await fetch('https://api.example.com', {
    headers: {
      Authorization: `Bearer ${await getVercelOidcToken()}`,
    },
  });

  return Response.json(await result.json());
};
```

### Managing Next.js Build Output Limits on Vercel

Source: https://context7_llms

This guide offers strategies for managing build output size limitations when using Next.js on Vercel. It covers techniques to reduce bundle size and optimize the build process to avoid exceeding limits.

```javascript
// Example: Code splitting in Next.js to reduce initial load and build size
import dynamic from 'next/dynamic';

const HeavyComponent = dynamic(() => import('../components/HeavyComponent'), {
  loading: () => <p>Loading...</p>,
  ssr: false, // Optional: disable server-side rendering for this component
});

function MyPage() {
  return (
    <div>
      <h1>Welcome</h1>
      <HeavyComponent /> {/* This component is loaded on demand */}
    </div>
  );
}

export default MyPage;

```

```js
import { redirect } from '@sveltejs/kit';

}

### Build E-commerce Sites with Next.js and Shopify API

Source: https://context7_llms

Learn to integrate Next.js with Shopify using the Storefront GraphQL API to create fast e-commerce storefronts. This guide focuses on leveraging the API for dynamic product and cart management.

```javascript
import { ApolloClient, InMemoryCache, gql } from '@apollo/client';

const client = new ApolloClient({
  uri: 'YOUR_SHOPIFY_GRAPHQL_ENDPOINT',
  headers: {
    'X-Shopify-Storefront-Access-Token': 'YOUR_STOREFRONT_ACCESS_TOKEN',
  },
  cache: new InMemoryCache(),
});

const GET_PRODUCTS = gql`
  query {
    products(first: 10) {
      edges {
        node {
          id
          title
          handle
          descriptionHtml
          images(first: 1) {
            edges {
              node {
                url
              }
            }
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
`;

async function fetchProducts() {
  try {
    const { data } = await client.query({ query: GET_PRODUCTS });
    return data.products.edges;
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error fetching products:', error);
    return [];
  }
}

// Example usage:
// fetchProducts().then(products => console.log(products));
```

### Legacy JSON Output with Python

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/ai-gateway/openai-compat

Illustrates the implementation of the legacy JSON output format using Python and the OpenAI SDK. It covers API key retrieval, client initialization, and sending a chat completion request with a predefined JSON schema. The example also shows how to parse the structured JSON response.

```python
import os
import json
from openai import OpenAI

api_key = os.getenv('AI_GATEWAY_API_KEY') or os.getenv('VERCEL_OIDC_TOKEN')

client = OpenAI(
    api_key=api_key,
    base_url='https://ai-gateway.vercel.sh/v1'
)

completion = client.chat.completions.create(
    model='openai/gpt-5',
    messages=[
        {
            'role': 'user',
            'content': 'Create a product listing for a wireless gaming headset.'
        }
    ],
    stream=False,
    response_format={
        'type': 'json',
        'name': 'product_listing',
        'description': 'A product listing with details and pricing',
        'schema': {
            'type': 'object',
            'properties': {
                'name': {'type': 'string', 'description': 'Product name'},
                'brand': {'type': 'string', 'description': 'Brand name'},
                'price': {'type': 'number', 'description': 'Price in USD'},
                'category': {'type': 'string', 'description': 'Product category'},
                'description': {'type': 'string', 'description': 'Product description'},
                'features': {
                    'type': 'array',
                    'items': {'type': 'string'},
                    'description': 'Key product features'
                }
            },
            'required': ['name', 'brand', 'price', 'category', 'description']
        }
    }
)

print('Assistant:', completion.choices[0].message.content)

# Parse the structured response
structured_data = json.loads(completion.choices[0].message.content)
print('Structured Data:', json.dumps(structured_data, indent=2))
```

### GitHub Action for Production Tag Deployment on Vercel

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/can-you-deploy-based-on-tags-releases-on-vercel

This GitHub Action automates production deployments to Vercel whenever a new tag is pushed. It requires Vercel CLI to be installed and uses environment secrets for authentication and project identification. The action checks out the code, installs Vercel CLI, pulls environment information, builds the project, and deploys the artifacts.

```yaml
name: Production Tag Deployment
env:
  VERCEL_ORG_ID: ${{ secrets.VERCEL_ORG_ID }}
  VERCEL_PROJECT_ID: ${{ secrets.VERCEL_PROJECT_ID }}
on:
  push:
    # Pattern matched against refs/tags
    tags:
      - '*'
jobs:
  Deploy-Production:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3
      - name: Install Vercel CLI
        run: npm install --global vercel@latest
      - name: Pull Vercel Environment Information
        run: vercel pull --yes --environment=production --token=${{ secrets.VERCEL_TOKEN }}
      - name: Build Project Artifacts
        run: vercel build --prod --token=${{ secrets.VERCEL_TOKEN }}
      - name: Deploy Project Artifacts to Vercel
        run: vercel deploy --prebuilt --prod --token=${{ secrets.VERCEL_TOKEN }}
```

### Astro CDN Cache-Control Headers Configuration

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/frameworks/frontend/astro

Example showing how to set different caching policies for Vercel's CDN and other downstream CDNs using 'Vercel-CDN-Cache-Control' and 'CDN-Cache-Control' headers. This example caches content for 3600 seconds on Vercel's CDN and 60 seconds on other CDNs.

```jsx
---
Astro.response.headers.set('Vercel-CDN-Cache-Control', 'max-age=3600');

const time = new Date().toLocaleTimeString();
---

<h1>{time}</h1>
```

### Update Installation Notification

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/integrations/create-integration/marketplace-api

Updates the notification field for a specific installation using the PATCH /v1/installations/{installationId} endpoint. Allows setting a title, message, optional href, and notification type.

```APIDOC
## PATCH /v1/installations/{installationId}

### Description
Updates the notification field for a specific installation. This can be used to display important information, warnings, or errors to the user associated with the installation.

### Method
PATCH

### Endpoint
`/v1/installations/{installationId}`

### Parameters
#### Path Parameters
- **installationId** (string) - Required - The unique identifier of the installation.

#### Request Body
- **notification** (object | null) - Optional - An object containing notification details or null to clear the notification.
  - **title** (string) - Required - The title of the notification.
  - **message** (string) - Required - The main content of the notification.
  - **href** (string) - Optional - A URL to link to. Can be a regular HTTPS URL or an `sso:` URL for authenticated access.
  - **type** (string) - Optional - The severity type of the notification. Allowed values: 'info', 'warning', 'error'. Defaults to 'info'.

### Request Example
```json
{
  "notification": {
    "title": "Action Required",
    "message": "Please complete your account setup",
    "href": "https://your-integration.com/setup",
    "type": "warning"
  }
}
```

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
- **id** (string) - The installation ID.
- **notification** (object | null) - The updated notification object or null if cleared.

#### Response Example
```json
{
  "id": "icfg_abc123",
  "notification": {
    "title": "Action Required",
    "message": "Please complete your account setup",
    "href": "https://your-integration.com/setup",
    "type": "warning"
  }
}
```
```

### Configure Vite for Server Entrypoint (JavaScript)

import {
  reactRouter,
} from '@react-router/dev/vite';

}));

### Get Project API

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/mcp/vercel-mcp/tools

Retrieves detailed information about a specific Vercel project.

```APIDOC
## get_project

### Description
Retrieve detailed information about a specific [project](/docs/projects) including framework, domains, and latest deployment.

### Method
GET

### Endpoint
/projects/{projectId}

### Parameters
#### Path Parameters
- **projectId** (string) - Required - The project ID or slug to get project details for. Project IDs start with 'prj*'. If not provided, it can be found through the `list_projects` tool or by reading `.vercel/project.json`.

#### Query Parameters
- **teamId** (string) - Required - The team ID or slug to get project details for. Team IDs start with 'team*'. If not provided, details for the personal account's project will be retrieved. Can be found using the `list_teams` tool or by reading `.vercel/project.json`.

#### Request Body
None

### Request Example
```json
{
  "tool_code": "get_project(projectId='prj_xyz789', teamId='team_abc123')"
}
```

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
- **project** (object) - Detailed information about the project.
  - **id** (string) - The project ID.
  - **slug** (string) - The project slug.
  - **framework** (string) - The project's framework.
  - **domains** (array) - A list of domains associated with the project.
  - **latestDeployment** (object) - Information about the latest deployment.

#### Response Example
```json

### Connection Pooling with Vercel Functions (Node.js)

Source: https://context7_llms

This guide outlines best practices for implementing connection pooling with Vercel Functions when connecting to relational databases. It emphasizes efficient database access patterns to manage connections effectively within serverless environments.

```javascript
import { Pool } from 'pg';

// Initialize a connection pool outside of the handler
// This allows the pool to be reused across invocations
const pool = new Pool({
  user: process.env.DB_USER,
  host: process.env.DB_HOST,
  database: process.env.DB_NAME,
  password: process.env.DB_PASSWORD,
  port: parseInt(process.env.DB_PORT || '5432'),
  max: 20, // Max number of clients in the pool
  idleTimeoutMillis: 30000, // How long a client is allowed to remain idle before closing
  connectionTimeoutMillis: 2000, // How long to wait for a connection to be established
});

export default async function handler(req, res) {
  let client;
  try {
    // Get a client from the pool
    client = await pool.connect();
    const result = await client.query('SELECT NOW()');
    res.status(200).json({ time: result.rows[0].now });
  } catch (err) {
    console.error('Error executing query', err.stack);
    res.status(500).json({ error: 'Database query failed' });
  } finally {
    // Release the client back to the pool
    if (client) {
      client.release();
    }
  }
}
```

### Build Weather API with Express and Vercel

Source: https://context7_llms

Learn to create a weather API using Express.js that can serve real-time weather data. This guide focuses on setting up a single Express route and deploying it to Vercel for easy access.

```JavaScript
import express from 'express';
import fetch from 'node-fetch';

const app = express();
const PORT = process.env.PORT || 3000;

app.get('/api/weather', async (req, res) => {
  const { city } = req.query;
  if (!city) {
    return res.status(400).json({ error: 'City parameter is required' });
  }

  try {
    const apiKey = process.env.WEATHER_API_KEY;
    const response = await fetch(`https://api.openweathermap.org/data/2.5/weather?q=${city}&appid=${apiKey}&units=metric`);
    const data = await response.json();

    if (data.cod !== 200) {
      return res.status(data.cod).json({ error: data.message });
    }

    res.json({
      city: data.name,
      temperature: data.main.temp,
      description: data.weather[0].description,
    });
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error fetching weather data:', error);
    res.status(500).json({ error: 'Failed to fetch weather data' });
  }
});

app.listen(PORT, () => {
  console.log(`Server running on port ${PORT}`);
});

// To deploy on Vercel, create an index.js file with this content and ensure you have a VERCEL_API_KEY environment variable set.
```

### POST /api/drains (Example)

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/drains/security

This endpoint receives data from Vercel drains and verifies the request signature. It's crucial for ensuring that the incoming requests are legitimate and originate from Vercel.

```APIDOC
## POST /api/drains

### Description
This endpoint handles incoming data from Vercel drains and verifies the `x-vercel-signature` header to ensure the request's authenticity. It uses a shared secret to hash the payload and compares it with the provided signature.

### Method
POST

### Endpoint
`/api/drains` (or your configured drain endpoint)

### Parameters

#### Query Parameters
None

#### Request Body
- **(raw body)** (string) - The raw payload sent by Vercel.

### Request Example
*(The request body will be the raw payload sent by Vercel. The `x-vercel-signature` header is crucial for verification.)*

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
- **success** (boolean) - Indicates if the request was processed successfully.

#### Error Response (403)
- **code** (string) - 'invalid_signature'
- **error** (string) - 'signature didn't match'

#### Response Example (Success)
```json
{
  "success": true
}
```

#### Response Example (Error)
```json
{
  "code": "invalid_signature",
  "error": "signature didn't match"
}
```

### Security
- **x-vercel-signature** (header) - The signature of the payload, generated using the Drain signature secret.

### Verification Process
1. Retrieve the `x-vercel-signature` header from the incoming request.
2. Obtain the raw request body.
3. Use your Drain signature secret to generate a SHA1 hash of the raw request body.
4. Compare the generated hash with the value in the `x-vercel-signature` header.
5. If they do not match, reject the request with a 403 status code.

### Code Snippets (Illustrative Examples)

**Node.js (Next.js App Router)**
```js
import crypto from 'crypto';

export async function POST(request) {
  const signatureSecret = process.env.VERCEL_DRAIN_SIGNATURE_SECRET;
  const rawBody = await request.text();
  const rawBodyBuffer = Buffer.from(rawBody, 'utf-8');
  const bodySignature = crypto.createHmac('sha1', signatureSecret).update(rawBodyBuffer).digest('hex');

  if (bodySignature !== request.headers.get('x-vercel-signature')) {
    return Response.json({ code: 'invalid_signature', error: "signature didn't match" }, { status: 403 });
  }

  console.log(rawBody);
  return Response.json({ success: true });
}
```

**Node.js (Next.js Pages Router)**
```js
import crypto from 'crypto';
import getRawBody from 'raw-body';

export default async function handler(request, response) {
  if (request.method !== 'POST') {
    return response.status(405).json({ error: 'Method not allowed' });
  }

  const signatureSecret = process.env.VERCEL_DRAIN_SIGNATURE_SECRET;
  const rawBody = await getRawBody(request);
  const bodySignature = crypto.createHmac('sha1', signatureSecret).update(rawBody).digest('hex');

  if (bodySignature !== request.headers['x-vercel-signature']) {
    return response.status(403).json({ code: 'invalid_signature', error: "signature didn't match" });
  }

  console.log(rawBody.toString()); // rawBody is a Buffer
  response.status(200).json({ success: true });
}

export const config = { api: { bodyParser: false } };
```

    }
  ],
  "rewrites": [

    },

      "destination": "/api/sharp"
    },

    },

### Hono Server Entrypoint with React Router (JavaScript)

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/frameworks/frontend/react-router

```javascript
import { Hono } from 'hono';
import { createRequestHandler } from 'react-router';

import * as build from 'virtual:react-router/server-build';

const app = new Hono();

// Add any additional Hono middleware here

const handler = createRequestHandler(build);
app.mount('/', (req) =>
  handler(req, {
    // Add your "load context" here based on the current request
    VALUE_FROM_HONO: 'Hello from Hono',
  }),
);

export default app.fetch;

### Stream LLM Reasoning Incrementally - Python

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/ai-gateway/openai-compat

This Python example demonstrates how to stream LLM responses with reasoning enabled using the `openai` Python library. It configures the client for Vercel's AI Gateway and iterates through the stream, separating and printing `delta.reasoning` from `delta.content`. Requires the `openai` package and an `AI_GATEWAY_API_KEY`.

```python
import os
from openai import OpenAI

client = OpenAI(
    api_key=os.getenv('AI_GATEWAY_API_KEY'),
    base_url='https://ai-gateway.vercel.sh/v1'
)

stream = client.chat.completions.create(
    model='anthropic/claude-sonnet-4',
    messages=[
        {
            'role': 'user',
            'content': 'What is the meaning of life? Think before answering.'
        }
    ],
    stream=True,
    extra_body={
        'reasoning': {
            'enabled': True
        }
    }
)

for chunk in stream:
    if chunk.choices and chunk.choices[0].delta:
        delta = chunk.choices[0].delta

        # Handle reasoning content
        if hasattr(delta, 'reasoning') and delta.reasoning:
            print(f"[Reasoning] {delta.reasoning}", end='', flush=True)

        # Handle regular content
        if hasattr(delta, 'content') and delta.content:
            print(delta.content, end='', flush=True)
```

### Secure Rewrites Configuration in Vercel

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/enhancing-security-for-redirects-and-rewrites

Demonstrates how to configure `rewrites` securely in Vercel by enforcing precise pattern restrictions on URI parameters. The vulnerable example allows any characters, while the secure example restricts the `id` parameter to only digits, preventing `userinfo` deception attacks.

```json
// âŒ Vulnerable {
  "rewrites": [
    {
      "source": "/user/:id*",
      "destination": "https://:id.example.com/"
    }
  ]
}

// âœ… Not vulnerable
{
  "rewrites": [
    {
      "source": "/user/:id(\d+)",
      "destination": "https://:id.example.com/"
    }
  ]
}
```

### Deploy Chained OpenAI LLM Calls with Inngest SDK (JavaScript)

Source: https://context7_llms

This guide explains how to deploy chained OpenAI LLM calls (like GPT-4) to Vercel using the Inngest SDK. It focuses on enabling multi-turn conversations, error correction, and complex AI interactions through sequential LLM processing.

```javascript
import { serve } from 'inngest/next';
import { OpenAI } from 'openai';

// Initialize OpenAI client
const openai = new OpenAI({ apiKey: process.env.OPENAI_API_KEY });

// Define your Inngest functions
export const inngest = serve({
  functions: [
    // Function to handle the first LLM call
    {
      id: 'first-llm-call',
      name: 'First LLM Call',
      trigger: { event: 'start.conversation' },
      async run({ event, step }) {
        const initialPrompt = event.data.prompt;

        // Step 1: Make the first call to OpenAI
        const firstResponse = await step.invoke('call-openai-1', async () => {
          const completion = await openai.chat.completions.create({
            model: 'gpt-4',
            messages: [{ role: 'user', content: initialPrompt }],
          });
          return completion.choices[0].message.content;
        });

        // Step 2: Use the result to make a second, chained call
        const secondResponse = await step.invoke('call-openai-2', async () => {
          const completion = await openai.chat.completions.create({
            model: 'gpt-4',
            messages: [
              { role: 'user', content: initialPrompt },
              { role: 'assistant', content: firstResponse },
              { role: 'user', content: 'Based on the above, provide a concise summary.' },
            ],
          });
          return completion.choices[0].message.content;
        });

        return { message: 'Chained LLM calls complete', finalResult: secondResponse };
      },
    },
  ],
});

```

### Configure Model Fallbacks using `models` Field (Python)

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/ai-gateway/openai-compat

This Python example demonstrates setting up model fallbacks via the `extra_body` parameter, using the `models` key. If the primary model fails, the listed fallback models (`openai/gpt-5-nano`, `gemini-2.0-flash`) are tried sequentially. The code employs the OpenAI Python client, connecting to the AI Gateway.

```python
import os
from openai import OpenAI

api_key = os.getenv('AI_GATEWAY_API_KEY') or os.getenv('VERCEL_OIDC_TOKEN')

client = OpenAI(
    api_key=api_key,
    base_url='https://ai-gateway.vercel.sh/v1'
)

completion = client.chat.completions.create(
    model='openai/gpt-4o',  # Primary model
    messages=[
        {
            'role': 'user',
            'content': 'Write a haiku about TypeScript.'
        }
    ],
    stream=False,
    # models is a gateway extension for fallback models
    extra_body={
        'models': ['openai/gpt-5-nano', 'gemini-2.0-flash']  # Fallback models
    }
)

print('Assistant:', completion.choices[0].message.content)

# Check which model was actually used
print('Model used:', completion.model);
```

### Challenge Cookie-less Requests with Vercel WAF API (JavaScript)

Source: https://context7_llms

This guide explains how to use the Vercel WAF API to challenge specific cookie-less requests. It details the implementation using JavaScript, outlining the necessary configurations and logic to apply security measures to targeted requests.

```javascript
import { NextResponse } from 'next/server';

export async function middleware(request) {
  const url = new URL(request.url);

  // Check if the request is cookie-less and matches a specific path
  if (!request.cookies.has('session') && url.pathname.startsWith('/protected')) {
    // Challenge the request using Vercel's WAF API (example: redirect to a challenge page)
    // In a real scenario, you might return a specific WAF challenge response
    return NextResponse.redirect(new URL('/challenge', request.url));
  }

  return NextResponse.next();
}
```

### Fetch All Products from Shopify using Next.js

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/building-ecommerce-sites-with-next-js-and-shopify

This function demonstrates how to fetch a list of products from Shopify using the previously defined `shopifyFetch` utility. It constructs a GraphQL query to retrieve product IDs, titles, and descriptions, limiting the results to the first 100 products sorted by title. This is a common pattern for populating product listings.

```javascript
export async function getAllProducts() {
  return shopifyFetch({
    query: `
      {
        products(sortKey: TITLE, first: 100) {
          edges {
            node {
              id
              title
              description
            }
          }
        }
      }
    `
  });
}
```

import { NextApiHandler } from 'next';

      clientSecret: process.env.GITHUB_SECRET,

};

### Redirect wildcard paths from /blog/ to /news/

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/project-configuration/vercel-ts

This example redirects paths under `/blog/` (e.g., `/blog/post1`) to corresponding paths under `/news/` (e.g., `/news/post1`) using wildcard matching and a 308 Permanent Redirect. Requires `@vercel/config/v1`.

### GitHub Actions: Vercel Preview Deployment Workflow

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/how-can-i-use-github-actions-with-vercel

This YAML workflow configures GitHub Actions to create a Vercel Preview Deployment for every push to a branch (excluding 'main'). It checks out code, installs the Vercel CLI, pulls environment information, builds artifacts, and deploys them to Vercel using the 'vercel deploy --prebuilt' command.

```yaml
name: Vercel Preview Deployment
env:
  VERCEL_ORG_ID: ${{ secrets.VERCEL_ORG_ID }}
  VERCEL_PROJECT_ID: ${{ secrets.VERCEL_PROJECT_ID }}

on:
  push:
    branches-ignore:
      - main

jobs:
  Deploy-Preview:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v2
      - name: Install Vercel CLI
        run: npm install --global vercel@latest
      - name: Pull Vercel Environment Information
        run: vercel pull --yes --environment=preview --token=${{ secrets.VERCEL_TOKEN }}
      - name: Build Project Artifacts
        run: vercel build --token=${{ secrets.VERCEL_TOKEN }}
      - name: Deploy Project Artifacts to Vercel
        run: vercel deploy --prebuilt --token=${{ secrets.VERCEL_TOKEN }}

### Streaming with Provider Options for Model Order (TypeScript)

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/ai-gateway/openai-compat

This TypeScript example shows how to configure the order of providers for streaming AI completions using `providerOptions.gateway.order`. It prioritizes `vertex` over `anthropic` if the initial `anthropic/claude-sonnet-4` model encounters issues. Requires the `openai` package.

```typescript
import OpenAI from 'openai';

const apiKey = process.env.AI_GATEWAY_API_KEY || process.env.VERCEL_OIDC_TOKEN;

const openai = new OpenAI({
  apiKey,
  baseURL: 'https://ai-gateway.vercel.sh/v1',
});

// @ts-expect-error
const stream = await openai.chat.completions.create({
  model: 'anthropic/claude-sonnet-4',
  messages: [
    {
      role: 'user',
      content:
        'Tell me the history of the San Francisco Mission-style burrito in two paragraphs.',
    },
  ],
  stream: true,
  providerOptions: {
    gateway: {
      order: ['vertex', 'anthropic'],
    },
  },
});

for await (const chunk of stream) {
  const content = chunk.choices[0]?.delta?.content;
  if (content) {
    process.stdout.write(content);
  }
}
```

### Upload File and Create Deployment with Vercel SDK (TypeScript)

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/ai-agents

This snippet demonstrates how to use the Vercel SDK in TypeScript to upload project files and create a deployment. It requires a Vercel bearer token and calculates a SHA1 hash for file integrity. The function returns the deployment object upon successful creation.

```typescript
import { Vercel } from "@vercel/sdk";
import crypto from "node:crypto";

const vercel = new Vercel({ bearerToken: "<YOUR_BEARER_TOKEN>" });
const teamId = process.env.TEAM_ID;

async function deployToVercel() {
  // Create your project files as a buffer
  const fileBuffer = /* your zipped project files as a buffer */;

  // Calculate SHA1 hash of the file
  const fileSha = crypto.createHash("sha1").update(fileBuffer).digest("hex");

  // 1. Upload the file to Vercel
  await vercel.deployments.uploadFile({
    teamId,
    headers: {
      "Content-Type": "application/octet-stream",
      "x-vercel-digest": fileSha,
      "Content-Length": fileBuffer.length.toString(),
    },
    body: fileBuffer,
  });

  // 2. Create deployment with the uploaded file
  const deployment = await vercel.deployments.createDeployment({
    teamId,
    requestBody: {
      files: [
        {
          file: ".vercel/source.tgz",
          sha: fileSha,
        },
      ],
      projectSettings: {
        framework: "nextjs",
      },
      name: `nextjs-deployment-${Date.now().toString(36)}`,
    },
  });

  return deployment;
}
```

### GitHub Actions Workflow for E2E Tests on Vercel Deployment Success

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/how-can-i-run-end-to-end-tests-after-my-vercel-preview-deployment

This GitHub Actions workflow is triggered by a 'repository_dispatch' event with the type 'vercel.deployment.success'. It checks out the specific commit, installs dependencies, installs Playwright with necessary browser dependencies, and then runs Playwright end-to-end tests. The 'BASE_URL' environment variable is set to the Vercel deployment URL provided in the client payload. This snippet is intended for integration with Vercel deployments.

```yaml
name: Playwright Tests

on:
  repository_dispatch:
    types:
      - 'vercel.deployment.success'

jobs:
  run-e2es:
    if: github.event_name == 'repository_dispatch'
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
        with:
          ref: ${{ github.event.client_payload.git.sha }}
      - name: Install dependencies
        run: npm ci && npx playwright install --with-deps
      - name: Run tests
        run: npx playwright test
        env:
          BASE_URL: ${{ github.event.client_payload.url }}
```

### Streaming with JSON Schema Output (Python)

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/ai-gateway/openai-compat

Example demonstrating how to use `json_schema` for structured streaming outputs with the OpenAI SDK in Python.

```APIDOC
## Streaming with JSON Schema Output (Python)

### Description
This Python example illustrates how to request structured data using `json_schema` in a streaming chat completion. It aggregates the streamed chunks and then parses the final JSON output.

### Method
POST

### Endpoint
`/v1/chat/completions`

### Parameters
#### Request Body
- **model** (string) - Required - The model to use for the chat completion.
- **messages** (list) - Required - A list of message dictionaries representing the conversation history.
- **stream** (boolean) - Required - If `True`, response chunks will be streamed.
- **response_format** (dict) - Required - Specifies the desired format for the response.
  - **type** (string) - Required - Must be `"json_schema"`.
  - **json_schema** (dict) - Required - A dictionary defining the schema.
    - **name** (string) - Required - A name for the schema.
    - **description** (string) - Required - A description of the schema's purpose.
    - **schema** (dict) - Required - The JSON schema definition.
      - **type** (string) - e.g., `"object"`
      - **properties** (dict) - Defines the object's properties.
      - **required** (list) - List of required properties.
      - **additionalProperties** (boolean) - Indicates if extra properties are allowed.

### Request Example
```python
import os
import json
from openai import OpenAI

client = OpenAI(
    api_key=os.getenv('AI_GATEWAY_API_KEY'),
    base_url='https://ai-gateway.vercel.sh/v1'
)

stream = client.chat.completions.create(
    model='openai/gpt-5',
    messages=[
        {
            'role': 'user',
            'content': 'Create a product listing for a wireless gaming headset.'
        }
    ],
    stream=True,
    response_format={
        'type': 'json_schema',
        'json_schema': {
            'name': 'product_listing',
            'description': 'A product listing with details and pricing',
            'schema': {
                'type': 'object',
                'properties': {
                    'name': {'type': 'string', 'description': 'Product name'},
                    'brand': {'type': 'string', 'description': 'Brand name'},
                    'price': {'type': 'number', 'description': 'Price in USD'},
                    'category': {'type': 'string', 'description': 'Product category'},
                    'description': {'type': 'string', 'description': 'Product description'},
                    'features': {
                        'type': 'array',
                        'items': {'type': 'string'},
                        'description': 'Key product features'
                    }
                },
                'required': ['name', 'brand', 'price', 'category', 'description'],
                'additionalProperties': False
            },
        }
    }
)

complete_response = ''
for chunk in stream:
    if chunk.choices and chunk.choices[0].delta.content:
        content = chunk.choices[0].delta.content
        print(content, end='', flush=True)
        complete_response += content

# Parse the complete structured response
structured_data = json.loads(complete_response)
print('\nParsed Product:', json.dumps(structured_data, indent=2))
```

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
- **content** (string) - A segment of the streamed output.

#### Response Example
(The complete streamed output, when parsed, will resemble this JSON structure)
```json
{
  "name": "Wireless Gaming Headset",
  "brand": "GamerGear",
  "price": 79.99,
  "category": "Electronics",
  "description": "High-performance wireless gaming headset with immersive audio and long-lasting battery life.",
  "features": [
    "2.4GHz Wireless Connection",
    "Noise-Cancelling Microphone",
    "30-Hour Battery Life",
    "Comfortable Over-Ear Design"
  ]
}
```

### Note
When utilizing structured outputs with streaming capabilities, it is essential to accumulate all received content chunks. The complete JSON response should only be parsed after the entire stream has concluded.
```

### Promote Canary Deployment After Approval (GitHub Actions)

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/implementing_canary_deployments_on_vercel

This workflow allows for manual promotion of a canary deployment to production. It installs the Vercel CLI, fetches the canary configuration from Edge Config, parses the canary deployment URL, promotes the deployment using the Vercel CLI, and finally updates the Edge Config to reflect that canary traffic is now 0%.

```yaml
name: Promote Canary Deployment
env:
  VERCEL_ORG_ID: ${{ secrets.VERCEL_ORG_ID }}
  VERCEL_PROJECT_ID: ${{ secrets.VERCEL_PROJECT_ID }}
  VERCEL_PROD_URL: ${{ secrets.VERCEL_PRODUCTION_DOMAIN }}
on:
  # Allow manual runs
  workflow_dispatch:
jobs:
  promote-canary-deployment:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Install Vercel CLI
        run: npm install --global vercel
      - name: Read Edge Config
        run: |
          curl 'https://edge-config.vercel.com/${{ secrets.VERCEL_EDGE_CONFIG_ID }}/item/canary-configuration \
          -H 'Authorization: Bearer ${{ secrets.EDGE_CONFIG_SECRET }}' \
          -o workflow.json
      - name: Parse Staged URL
        id: canary
        run: |
          echo "url=$(cat workflow.json | jq -c '.deploymentDomainCanary')" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
      - name: Promote Vercel Deployment
        run: vercel promote ${{ steps.canary.outputs.url }} --token=${{ secrets.VERCEL_TOKEN }} --scope jasonwikerentdemo
      - name: Update Edge Config
        run: |
          curl -X 'PATCH' 'https://api.vercel.com/v1/edge-config/${{ secrets.VERCEL_EDGE_CONFIG_ID }}/items?teamId=${{ secrets.VERCEL_ORG_ID }}' \
          -H 'Authorization: Bearer ${{ secrets.VERCEL_TOKEN }}' \
          -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
          -d $'{ "items": [ { "operation": "upsert", "key": "canary-configuration", "value": { "deploymentDomainExisting": "${{ env.VERCEL_PROD_URL }}", "deploymentDomainCanary": "${{ steps.canary.outputs.url }}", "trafficCanaryPercent": 0 } } ] }'
```

### LaunchDarkly Feature Flag Evaluation in Middleware

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/edge-config/edge-config-integrations/launchdarkly-edge-config

This middleware function initializes LaunchDarkly from the server if needed, evaluates the 'experimental-homepage' feature flag for a given organization context, and redirects to a new homepage if the flag is enabled. It requires the LaunchDarkly client and the Edge Config client.

```typescript
export default function middleware(request) {
  await launchDarklyClient.initFromServerIfNeeded();
  const launchDarklyContext = { kind: 'org', key: 'my-org-key' };
  const showExperimentalHomepage = await launchDarklyClient.variation(
    'experimental-homepage',
    launchDarklyContext,
    true
  );

  if(showExperimentalHomepage) {
    const url = new URL(request.url);
    url.pathname = '/new-homepage';
    return Response.redirect(url);
  }
}
```

### Managing Session Data with Redis in Next.js

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/session-store-nextjs-redis-vercel-kv

Offers functions to interact with the Redis store for session data. `get` retrieves a specific key's value, `getAll` fetches all key-value pairs for a session, and `set` stores a key-value pair. These functions utilize session IDs and an optional namespace for data segregation, interacting with Redis via `hget`, `hgetall`, and `hset` commands.

```typescript
export async function get(key: string, namespace: string = "") {
  const sessionId = await getSessionId();
  if (!sessionId) {
    return null;
  }
  return redis.hget(`session-${namespace}-${sessionId}`, key);
}

export async function getAll(namespace: string = "") {
  const sessionId = await getSessionId();
  if (!sessionId) {
    return null;
  }
  return redis.hgetall(`session-${namespace}-${sessionId}`);
}

export async function set(key: string, value: string, namespace: string = "") {
  const sessionId = await getSessionIdAndCreateIfMissing();
  return redis.hset(`session-${namespace}-${sessionId}`, key, value);
}
```

import { NextResponse } from 'next/server';

export async function GET(request) {
  const response = NextResponse.json({ message: 'Hello, World!' });
  response.headers.set('Cache-Control', 'public, s-maxage=3600, stale-while-revalidate=86400');
  return response;
}

### Using External Image as OG Image

Source: https://context7_llms

This guide explains how to use an external image as your OG image by passing a username as a URL parameter. This allows for dynamic image generation based on user-specific data.

```typescript
import { ImageResponse } from "@vercel/og";

export const config = {
  runtime: "edge",
};

export default async function handler(request: Request) {
  const { searchParams } = new URL(request.url);
  const username = searchParams.get("username");

  const avatar = fetch(new URL(`./${username}.png`, import.meta.url)).then(
    (res) => res.arrayBuffer()
  );
  const [imageData] = await Promise.all([avatar]);

  return new ImageResponse(
    (
      <div
        style={{
          display: "flex",
          flexDirection: "column",
          alignItems: "center",
          justifyContent: "center",
          width: "100%",
          height: "100%",
          background: "#f0f0f0",
          fontSize: 40,
        }}
      >
        <img
          src={new URL(
            `https://example.com/api/user/${username}/avatar`,
            request.url
          ).toString()}
          alt="User Avatar"
          width="200"
          height="200"
        />
        <p>User: {username}</p>
      </div>
    ),
    {
      width: 1200,
      height: 630,
    }
  );
}
```

  - **completedAt** (number) - A timestamp that tells you when the configuration was installed successfully. Example: `1558531915505`

  - **type** (string) - The type of the configuration (e.g., 'integration-configuration').

### Configure Vercel Analytics User Opt-Out in HTML

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/analytics/redacting-sensitive-data

This example illustrates how to implement user opt-out for Vercel Analytics directly within an HTML file using a script tag. The `window.va` function is defined, and a 'beforeSend' event listener is added. If `localStorage.getItem('va-disable')` returns a value, the event is nullified, preventing tracking. This is useful for static sites or environments without a build process.

```javascript
<script>
  window.va = function () {
    (window.vaq = window.vaq || []).push(arguments);
  };
  window.va('beforeSend', (event) => {
    if (localStorage.getItem('va-disable')) {
      return null;
    }
    return event;
  });
</script>
```

```typescript
<script>
  window.va = function () {
    (window.vaq = window.vaq || []).push(arguments);
  };
  window.va('beforeSend', (event) => {
    if (localStorage.getItem('va-disable')) {
      return null;
    }
    return event;
  });
</script>
```

### GET /llmstxt/vercel_llms_txt/configurations

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/rest-api/reference/endpoints/integrations/retrieve-an-integration-configuration

Retrieves integration configurations for the authenticated user or team. You can filter by configuration ID.

```APIDOC
## GET /llmstxt/vercel_llms_txt/configurations

### Description
Retrieves integration configurations for the authenticated user or team. You can filter by configuration ID.

### Method
GET

### Endpoint
/llmstxt/vercel_llms_txt/configurations

### Parameters
#### Query Parameters
- **id** (string) - Required - ID of the configuration to check. Example: `"icfg_cuwj0AdCdH3BwWT4LPijCC7t"`
- **teamId** (string) - Optional - The Team identifier to perform the request on behalf of. Example: `"team_1a2b3c4d5e6f7g8h9i0j1k2l"`
- **slug** (string) - Optional - The Team slug to perform the request on behalf of. Example: `"my-team-url-slug"`

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
- **projectSelection** (enum) - Required - A string representing the permission for projects. Possible values are `all` or `selected`. Available options: `selected`, `all`. Example: `"all"`
- **notification** (object) - Required - Show child attributes
- **transferRequest** (object) - Required - Show child attributes
- **createdAt** (number) - Required - A timestamp that tells you when the configuration was created. Example: `1558531915505`
- **id** (string) - Required - The unique identifier of the configuration. Example: `"icfg_3bwCLgxL8qt5kjRLcv2Dit7F"`
- **integrationId** (string) - Required - The unique identifier of the app the configuration was created for. Example: `"oac_xzpVzcUOgcB1nrVlirtKhbWV"`
- **ownerId** (string) - Required - The user or team ID that owns the configuration. Example: `"kr1PsOIzqEL5Xg6M4VZcZosf"`
- **slug** (string) - Required - The slug of the integration the configuration is created for. Example: `"slack"`
- **updatedAt** (number) - Required - A timestamp that tells you when the configuration was updated. Example: `1558531915505`
- **userId** (string) - Required - The ID of the user that created the configuration. Example: `"kr1PsOIzqEL5Xg6M4VZcZosf"`
- **scopes** (string[]) - Required - The resources that are allowed to be accessed by the configuration. Example: `["read:project", "read-write:log-drain"]`
- **type** (enum) - Required - Available options: `integration-configuration`
- **projects** (string[]) - Optional - When a configuration is limited to access certain projects, this will contain each of the project ID it is allowed to access. If it is not defined, the configuration has full access. Example: `["prj_xQxbutw1HpL6HLYPAzt5h75m8NjO"]`
- **completedAt** (number) - Optional - A timestamp that tells you when the configuration was installed successfully. Example: `1558531915505`
- **teamId** (string | null) - Optional - When the configuration was created for a team, this will show the ID of the team. Example: `"team_nLlpyC6RE1qxydlFKbrxDlud"`
- **disabledAt** (number) - Optional - A timestamp that tells you when the configuration was disabled. Note: Configurations can be disabled when the associated user loses access to a team. They do not function during this time until the configuration is 'transferred', meaning the associated user is changed to one with access to the team. Example: `1558531915505`
- **disabledReason** (enum) - Optional - Available options: `disabled-by-owner`, `feature-not-available`, `disabled-by-admin`, `original-owner-left-the-team`, `account-plan-downgrade`, `original-owner-role-downgraded`
- **source** (string) - Optional - Source defines where the configuration was installed from. It is used to analyze user engagement for integration installations in product metrics. Example: `"marketplace"`
- **canConfigureOpenTelemetry** (boolean) - Optional
- **installationType** (enum) - Optional - Defines the installation type. - 'external' integrations are installed via the existing integrations flow - 'marketplace' integrations are natively installed: - when accepting the TOS of a partner during the store creation process - if undefined, assume 'external'. Available options: `marketplace`, `external`
- **deleteRequestedAt** (number | null) - Optional - A timestamp that tells you when the configuration deletion has been started for cases when the deletion needs to be settled/approved by partners, such as when marketplace invoices have been paid. Example: `1558531915505`
- **status** (enum) - Optional - The configuration status. Optional. If not defined, assume 'ready'. Available options: `pending`, `ready`, `onboarding`, `suspended`, `resumed`, `error`, `uninstalled`
- **externalId** (string) - Optional - An external identifier defined by the integration vendor.
- **deletedAt** (number | null) - Optional - A timestamp that tells you when the configuration was deleted. Example: `1558531915505`

#### Response Example
```json
{
  "projectSelection": "all",
  "notification": {},
  "transferRequest": {},
  "createdAt": 1558531915505,
  "id": "icfg_3bwCLgxL8qt5kjRLcv2Dit7F",
  "integrationId": "oac_xzpVzcUOgcB1nrVlirtKhbWV",
  "ownerId": "kr1PsOIzqEL5Xg6M4VZcZosf",
  "slug": "slack",
  "updatedAt": 1558531915505,
  "userId": "kr1PsOIzqEL5Xg6M4VZcZosf",
  "scopes": [
    "read:project",
    "read-write:log-drain"
  ],
  "type": "integration-configuration",
  "projects": [
    "prj_xQxbutw1HpL6HLYPAzt5h75m8NjO"
  ],
  "completedAt": 1558531915505,
  "teamId": "team_nLlpyC6RE1qxydlFKbrxDlud",
  "disabledAt": 1558531915505,
  "disabledReason": "disabled-by-owner",
  "source": "marketplace",
  "canConfigureOpenTelemetry": true,
  "installationType": "marketplace",
  "deleteRequestedAt": 1558531915505,
  "status": "ready",
  "externalId": "some_external_id",
  "deletedAt": null
}
```

### Generate Text with Tool Calling and Multi-Step Reasoning (TypeScript)

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/how-to-build-ai-agents-with-vercel-and-the-ai-sdk

This snippet demonstrates how to use `generateText` with defined tools and configure multi-step reasoning using `stopWhen` and `stepCountIs`. It includes example tools for fetching weather and activities, specifying their descriptions and parameters using Zod. The `execute` function simulates tool execution.

```typescript
import { generateText, tool, stepCountIs } from 'ai';
import { z } from 'zod';

export async function getWeather({location}: string) {
  const { text } = await generateText({
    model: 'openai/gpt-5',
    prompt: `What is the weather in ${location}?`,
    stopWhen: stepCountIs(5), // Allow up to 5 steps
    tools: {
      weather: tool({
        description: 'Get the weather in a location',
        parameters: z.object({
          location: z.string().describe('The location to get the weather for'),
        }),
        execute: async ({ location }) => ({
          location,
          temperature: 72 + Math.floor(Math.random() * 21) - 10,
        }),
      }),
      activities: tool({
        description: 'Get the activities in a location',
        parameters: z.object({
          location: z.string().describe('The location to get the activities for'),
        }),
        execute: async ({ location }) => ({
          location,
          activities: ['hiking', 'swimming', 'sightseeing'],
        }),
      }),
    },
  });

  console.log(text);
}
```

### Billing Events Webhooks

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/integrations/create-integration/marketplace-api

This section details the available billing events that can be received via webhooks and provides examples of how to handle them. Verifying webhook signatures is crucial for security.

```APIDOC
## Billing Webhook Events

This API allows you to receive real-time notifications about billing events. By implementing webhook handlers, you can automate actions based on invoice status changes.

### Supported Events

- `marketplace.invoice.created`: Triggered when an invoice is created and sent to the customer.
- `marketplace.invoice.paid`: Triggered when an invoice is successfully paid.
- `marketplace.invoice.notpaid`: Triggered when an invoice is not paid after a grace period.
- `marketplace.invoice.refunded`: Triggered when an invoice is refunded.

### Webhook Security

To ensure the integrity and authenticity of incoming webhook requests, it is essential to verify webhook signatures using your **Integration Secret** (Client Secret). Refer to the [Securing webhooks](/docs/webhooks/webhooks-api#securing-webhooks) section for detailed instructions.

## Handle Invoice Created Event

This handler is invoked when a new invoice is created. It is useful for logging, updating internal records, or sending initial notifications.

### Event
`marketplace.invoice.created`

### Request Body Example

{
  "id": "evt_abc123",
  "type": "marketplace.invoice.created",
  "payload": {
    "invoice": {
      "id": "inv_xyz789",
      "installationId": "icfg_def456",
      "amount": 29.99,
      "currency": "USD",
      "createdAt": "2025-01-15T10:00:00Z"
    }
  }
}

  "message": "Invoice created event processed successfully."
}

This handler is triggered upon successful payment of an invoice. Use this to activate resources, update billing status, or notify users.

`marketplace.invoice.paid`

{

### Calling Tools and MCP Clients with TypeScript

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/how-to-build-ai-app

Demonstrates how to use the AI SDK to call external tools and interact with Model Context Protocols (MCP). It shows setting up an MCP client, fetching available tools, and defining a tool with input schema and execution logic. This enables the model to gather information or perform actions by interacting with external systems.

```typescript
import { generateText, tool } from 'ai';
import { openai } from '@ai-sdk/openai';
import { experimental_createMCPClient as createMCPClient } from 'ai';
import { z } from 'zod';

// Create MCP client for external tools
const mcpClient = await createMCPClient({
  transport: {
    type: 'sse',
    url: 'https://travel-api.com/mcp',
  },
});

const mcpTools = await mcpClient.tools();

const result = await generateText({
  model: openai('gpt-4'),
  prompt: 'Plan a 3-day trip to London for next month',
  tools: {
    calculateBudget: tool({
      description: 'Calculate total trip budget',
      inputSchema: z.object({
        flights: z.number(),
        hotels: z.number(),
        activities: z.number(),
      }),
      execute: async ({ flights, hotels, activities }) => {
        return flights + hotels + activities;
      },
    }),
    ...mcpTools,
  },
});
```

### Streaming with JSON Schema Output (TypeScript)

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/ai-gateway/openai-compat

Example demonstrating how to use `json_schema` for structured streaming outputs with the OpenAI SDK in TypeScript.

```APIDOC
## Streaming with JSON Schema Output (TypeScript)

### Description
This example shows how to create a chat completion request with streaming enabled and a `json_schema` response format. It then iterates through the stream to collect the complete response and parses it as JSON.

### Method
POST

### Endpoint
`/v1/chat/completions`

### Parameters
#### Request Body
- **model** (string) - Required - The model to use for the chat completion.
- **messages** (array) - Required - An array of message objects representing the conversation history.
- **stream** (boolean) - Required - If set to `true`, streaming of response chunks will be enabled.
- **response_format** (object) - Required - Specifies the desired format for the response.
  - **type** (string) - Required - Must be `"json_schema"`.
  - **json_schema** (object) - Required - An object containing the schema definition.
    - **name** (string) - Required - A name for the schema.
    - **description** (string) - Required - A description of what the schema represents.
    - **schema** (object) - Required - The JSON schema definition.
      - **type** (string) - e.g., `"object"`
      - **properties** (object) - Defines the properties of the object.
      - **required** (array) - List of required properties.
      - **additionalProperties** (boolean) - Whether additional properties are allowed.

### Request Example
```typescript
import OpenAI from 'openai';

const openai = new OpenAI({
  apiKey: process.env.AI_GATEWAY_API_KEY,
  baseURL: 'https://ai-gateway.vercel.sh/v1',
});

const stream = await openai.chat.completions.create({
  model: 'openai/gpt-5',
  messages: [
    {
      role: 'user',
      content: 'Create a product listing for a wireless gaming headset.',
    },
  ],
  stream: true,
  response_format: {
    type: 'json_schema',
    json_schema: {
      name: 'product_listing',
      description: 'A product listing with details and pricing',
      schema: {
        type: 'object',
        properties: {
          name: { type: 'string', description: 'Product name' },
          brand: { type: 'string', description: 'Brand name' },
          price: { type: 'number', description: 'Price in USD' },
          category: { type: 'string', description: 'Product category' },
          description: { type: 'string', description: 'Product description' },
          features: {
            type: 'array',
            items: { type: 'string' },
            description: 'Key product features',
          },
        },
        required: ['name', 'brand', 'price', 'category', 'description'],
        additionalProperties: false,
      },
    },
  },
});

let completeResponse = '';
for await (const chunk of stream) {
  const content = chunk.choices[0]?.delta?.content;
  if (content) {
    process.stdout.write(content);
    completeResponse += content;
  }
}

// Parse the complete structured response
const structuredData = JSON.parse(completeResponse);
console.log('\nParsed Product:', structuredData);
```

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
- **content** (string) - A chunk of the streamed response.

#### Response Example
(Streamed output that forms a JSON object upon completion)
```json
{
  "name": "Wireless Gaming Headset",
  "brand": "GamerGear",
  "price": 79.99,
  "category": "Electronics",
  "description": "High-performance wireless gaming headset with immersive audio and long-lasting battery life.",
  "features": [
    "2.4GHz Wireless Connection",
    "Noise-Cancelling Microphone",
    "30-Hour Battery Life",
    "Comfortable Over-Ear Design"
  ]
}
```

### Note
When using structured outputs with streaming, you must collect all content chunks and parse the complete JSON response after the stream finishes.
```

### Fix Missing Dependencies in Vercel Builds (NPM/Yarn)

Source: https://context7_llms

This guide addresses the common issue of missing dependencies in Vercel builds. It explains potential causes, such as incorrect `package.json` configurations or issues with package managers (NPM/Yarn), and provides steps to resolve them.

```plaintext
## Troubleshooting Missing Dependencies on Vercel

**Common Causes:**

1.  **Incorrect `package.json`:** Ensure all necessary dependencies are listed under `dependencies` (for production) or `devDependencies` (if needed only during build).
2.  **Private Packages:** If using private npm packages, ensure Vercel has access via npm tokens or Vercel's integration settings.
3.  **Monorepo Issues:** In monorepos (e.g., using Yarn Workspaces or pnpm), ensure the Vercel build command correctly installs dependencies for all workspaces.
4.  **Cache Problems:** Sometimes, stale build caches can cause issues. Triggering a new build or clearing the cache might help.
5.  **Package Manager Version:** Ensure consistency between your local package manager version and the one used by Vercel (usually auto-detected or configurable).

**Resolution Steps:**

*   **Verify `package.json`:** Double-check the `dependencies` section.
    ```json
    // Example package.json snippet
    {
      "dependencies": {
        "react": "^18.2.0",
        "next": "13.5.4"
      },
      "devDependencies": {
        "eslint": "8.50.0"
      }
    }
    ```
*   **Check Vercel Build Logs:** Look for specific error messages related to `npm install` or `yarn install`.
*   **Force a Rebuild:** Deploy again or use Vercel's options to redeploy.
*   **Consider `npm ci`:** If you encounter issues with `npm install`, try using `npm ci` in your build command, which installs exact versions from `package-lock.json`.
*   **Monorepo Specifics:** Ensure your `vercel.json` or build command correctly points to the root `package.json` or workspace configuration.
```

### Image Analysis using Bash and JavaScript

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/ai-gateway/openai-compat

Demonstrates how to analyze an image using the Vercel AI Gateway. The image is first converted to a base64 string and then included in the request content. This example requires an API key and the image file path.

```bash
# First, convert your image to base64
IMAGE_BASE64=$(base64 -i ./path/to/image.png)

curl -X POST "https://ai-gateway.vercel.sh/v1/chat/completions" \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $AI_GATEWAY_API_KEY" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "model": "anthropic/claude-sonnet-4",
    "messages": [
      {
        "role": "user",
        "content": [
          {
            "type": "text",
            "text": "Describe this image in detail."
          },
          {
            "type": "image_url",
            "image_url": {
              "url": "data:image/png;base64,'"$IMAGE_BASE64"'",
              "detail": "auto"
            }
          }
        ]
      }
    ],
    "stream": false
  }'
```

```javascript
import fs from 'node:fs';

// Read the image file as base64
const imageBuffer = fs.readFileSync('./path/to/image.png');
const imageBase64 = imageBuffer.toString('base64');

const response = await fetch(
  'https://ai-gateway.vercel.sh/v1/chat/completions',
  {
    method: 'POST',
    headers: {
      Authorization: `Bearer ${process.env.AI_GATEWAY_API_KEY}`,
      'Content-Type': 'application/json',
    },
    body: JSON.stringify({
      model: 'anthropic/claude-sonnet-4',
      messages: [
        {
          role: 'user',
          content: [
            { type: 'text', text: 'Describe this image in detail.' },
            {
              type: 'image_url',
              image_url: {
                url: `data:image/png;base64,${imageBase64}`,
                detail: 'auto',
              },
            },
          ],
        },
      ],
      stream: false,
    }),
  },
);

const result = await response.json();
console.log(result);
```

### GraphQL Fragment Colocation Example (JavaScript/TypeScript)

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/building-nextjs-apps-with-graphql-fragment-colocation-and-sanity-cms

Demonstrates how to define and compose GraphQL fragments for component-level data declarations that resolve into a single page query. This pattern enhances type safety, component isolation, and reduces API requests.

```javascript
// Each component declares its data needs as a fragment
const postHeaderFragment = graphql(`
  fragment PostHeader on Post {
    title
    publishedAt
  }
`);
export const authorFragment = graphql(`
  fragment Author on Author {
    _id
    name
    bio
  }
`);

// All fragments compose into a single page query
const GET_POST_BY_SLUG = graphql(
  `
  query GetPostBySlug($slug: String!) {
    allPost(where: { slug: { current: { eq: $slug } } }, limit: 1) {
      excerpt
      contentRaw
      author {
        ...Author
      }
      ...PostHeader
    }
  }
`,
  [authorFragment, postHeaderFragment]
);

const { getClient } = registerUrql(createGraphQLClient);

// Single API request, full type safety, component isolation
export default async function HomePage() {
  const { data } = await getClient().query(GET_POST_BY_SLUG, { slug });

  return (
    <>
      <PostHeader data={data} />
      <Author data={data.author} />
    </>
  );
}
```

### Replacing Durable Objects with Redis for Stateful Streams

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/migrate-to-vercel-from-cloudflare

Provides an example of how to manage stateful streams using the 'resumable-stream' library with Redis as a backend. This approach offers an alternative to Cloudflare Durable Objects for scenarios like Server-Sent Events (SSE) where clients might disconnect and reconnect. It leverages Redis for pub/sub and data storage to maintain stream positions.

```javascript
import { ResumableStream } from 'resumable-stream';
import Redis from 'ioredis';

// Assuming Redis is configured via environment variables or explicitly
const redisClient = new Redis(process.env.REDIS_URL);

const stream = new ResumableStream({
  redis: redisClient,
  streamId: 'my-sse-stream',
  // other configuration options...
});

// To send messages:
// stream.sendToSubscribers('Hello world!');

// To subscribe (e.g., in a Vercel Function):
// stream.subscribe().then(subscriber => {
//   subscriber.on('message', (message) => {
//     console.log('Received message:', message);
//   });
// });

// For atomic operations like counters or locks:
// const redis = new Redis(process.env.REDIS_URL);
// await redis.incr('my-counter'); // Atomic increment
// await redis.setnx('my-lock', 'locked'); // Atomic set if not exists
```

### Automating with AI Agents and Tools in TypeScript

Source: https://vercel.com/kb/guide/how-to-build-ai-app

```typescript
import { generateText, tool, stepCountIs } from 'ai';
import { openai } from '@ai-sdk/openai';
import { searchFlights, findHotels } from '@/lib/tools';

const result = await generateText({
  model: openai('gpt-4'),
  stopWhen: stepCountIs(5),
  system: 'You are a travel planning agent. ' +
          'Break down the trip planning into steps. ' +
          'Use available tools to gather information and make decisions.',
  prompt: 'Plan a 3-day trip to London for next month',
  tools: {
    searchFlights,
    findHotels,
  },
});
```

```javascript

import { inject } from '@vercel/analytics';

inject({
  beforeSend: (event) => {
    if (event.url.includes('/private')) {
      return null;
    }
    return event;
  },
});

### Custom Server File for Remix on Vercel

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/frameworks/full-stack/remix

Demonstrates how to create a custom `server.js` or `server.ts` file for a Remix application deployed on Vercel. This requires installing `@vercel/remix` and using `createRequestHandler` from its server module. Note that this is not supported when using the Remix Vite plugin.

```js
import { createRequestHandler } from '@vercel/remix/server';
import * as build from '@remix-run/dev/server-build';

export default createRequestHandler({
  build,
  mode: process.env.NODE_ENV,
  getLoadContext() {
    return {
      nodeLoadContext: true,
    };
  },
});
```

```ts
import { createRequestHandler } from '@vercel/remix/server';
import * as build from '@remix-run/dev/server-build';

export default createRequestHandler({
  build,
  mode: process.env.NODE_ENV,
  getLoadContext() {
    return {
      nodeLoadContext: true,
    };
  },
});
```

### GET /v6/deployments - List Deployments

Source: https://vercel.com/docs/rest-api/reference/endpoints/deployments/list-deployments

Retrieves a list of deployments under the authenticated user or team. The `url` property will be `null` if a deployment is incomplete.

```APIDOC
## GET /v6/deployments

### Description
Lists deployments associated with the authenticated user or team. Returns `null` for the `url` if the deployment is not yet complete.

### Method
GET

### Endpoint
`/v6/deployments`

### Parameters
#### Query Parameters
- **app** (string) - Optional - Filter deployments by application name.
- **from** (integer) - Optional - Filter deployments created after this timestamp.
- **limit** (integer) - Optional - The maximum number of deployments to return.
- **projectId** (string) - Optional - Filter deployments by project ID.
- **projectIds** (array of strings) - Optional - Filter deployments by a list of project IDs.
- **target** (string) - Optional - Filter deployments by target environment (e.g., 'production').
- **to** (integer) - Optional - Filter deployments created before this timestamp.
- **users** (string) - Optional - Filter deployments by a comma-separated list of user IDs.
- **since** (integer) - Optional - Filter deployments created since this timestamp.
- **until** (integer) - Optional - Filter deployments created until this timestamp.
- **state** (string) - Optional - Filter deployments by their state (e.g., 'BUILDING,READY').
- **teamId** (string) - Optional - Filter deployments by team ID.
- **slug** (string) - Optional - Filter deployments by team URL slug.

### Request Example
```json
{
  "app": "docs",
  "from": 1612948664566,
  "limit": 10,
  "projectId": "QmXGTs7mvAMMC7WW5ebrM33qKG32QK3h4vmQMjmY",
  "projectIds": [
    "prj_123",
    "prj_456"
  ],
  "target": "production",
  "to": 1612948664566,
  "users": "kr1PsOIzqEL5Xg6M4VZcZosf,K4amb7K9dAt5R2vBJWF32bmY",
  "since": 1540095775941,
  "until": 1540095775951,
  "state": "BUILDING,READY",
  "teamId": "team_1a2b3c4d5e6f7g8h9i0j1k2l",
  "slug": "my-team-url-slug"
}
```

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
- **pagination** (object) - Contains information about the pagination of the results.
  - **count** (integer) - The total number of deployments.
  - **next** (integer) - The timestamp for the next page of results.
  - **prev** (integer) - The timestamp for the previous page of results.
- **deployments** (array of objects) - A list of deployment objects.
  - **uid** (string) - Unique identifier for the deployment.
  - **name** (string) - The name of the deployment.
  - **projectId** (string) - The ID of the project the deployment belongs to.
  - **url** (string) - The URL of the deployment. `null` if incomplete.
  - **created** (integer) - Timestamp when the deployment was created.
  - **type** (string) - The type of the deployment (e.g., 'LAMBDAS').
  - **creator** (object) - Information about the user who created the deployment.
  - **inspectorUrl** (string) - URL for the Vercel inspector.
  - **defaultRoute** (string) - The default route for the deployment.
  - **deleted** (integer) - Timestamp when the deployment was deleted.
  - **undeleted** (integer) - Timestamp when the deployment was undeleted.
  - **softDeletedByRetention** (boolean) - Indicates if the deployment was soft-deleted by retention policy.
  - **source** (string) - The source of the deployment (e.g., 'cli').
  - **state** (string) - The current state of the deployment (e.g., 'READY').
  - **readyState** (string) - The ready state of the deployment.
  - **meta** (object) - Metadata associated with the deployment.
  - **target** (string) - The target environment for the deployment.
  - **aliasError** (object) - Error details if an alias failed.
  - **aliasAssigned** (integer) - Timestamp when the alias was assigned.
  - **createdAt** (integer) - Timestamp when the deployment was created.
  - **buildingAt** (integer) - Timestamp when the deployment started building.
  - **ready** (integer) - Timestamp when the deployment became ready.
  - **readySubstate** (string) - The substate of the deployment being ready.
  - **checksState** (string) - The state of the deployment checks.
  - **checksConclusion** (string) - The conclusion of the deployment checks.
  - **checks** (object) - Details about the deployment checks.
  - **errorCode** (string) - An error code if the deployment failed.
  - **errorMessage** (string) - An error message if the deployment failed.
  - **oomReport** (string) - Out-of-memory report if applicable.
  - **isRollbackCandidate** (boolean) - Indicates if this deployment can be rolled back to.
  - **prebuilt** (boolean) - Indicates if the deployment was prebuilt.
  - **projectSettings** (object) - Settings for the associated project.
  - **connectBuildsEnabled** (boolean) - Indicates if connect builds are enabled.
  - **connectConfigurationId** (string) - The ID of the connect configuration.
  - **passiveConnectConfigurationId** (string) - The ID of the passive connect configuration.
  - **expiration** (integer) - Timestamp when the deployment will expire.
  - **proposedExpiration** (integer) - Proposed expiration timestamp for the deployment.
  - **customEnvironment** (object) - Custom environment details for the deployment.

#### Response Example
```json

    "count": 20,
    "next": 1540095775951,
    "prev": 1540095775951
  },
  "deployments": [
    {
